CODE COMMENTARY
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 275
CHAPTER 16 — PRECAST CONCRETE
CODE COMMENTARY
16.1 — Scope R16.1 — Scope
16.1.1 — All provisions of this Code, not specifically R16.1.1 — See 2.2 for definition of precast concrete.
excluded and not in conflict with the provisions of
Chapter 16, shall apply to structures incorporating Design and construction requirements for precast concrete
precast concrete structural members. structural members differ in some respects from those for
cast-in-place concrete structural members and these differ-
ences are addressed in this chapter. Where provisions for
cast-in-place concrete applied to precast concrete, they have
not been repeated. Similarly, items related to composite
concrete in Chapter 17 and to prestressed concrete in
Chapter 18 that apply to precast concrete are not restated.
More detailed recommendations concerning precast concrete
are given in References 16.1 through 16.7. Tilt-up concrete
construction is a form of precast concrete. It is recommended
that Reference 16.8 be reviewed for tilt-up structures.
16.2 — General R16.2 — General
16.2.1 — Design of precast members and connections R16.2.1 — Stresses developed in precast members during
shall include loading and restraint conditions from the period from casting to final connection may be greater
initial fabrication to end use in the structure, including than the service load stresses. Handling procedures may
form removal, storage, transportation, and erection. cause undesirable deformations. Care should be given to the
methods of storing, transporting, and erecting precast
members so that performance at service loads and strength
under factored loads meet Code requirements.
16.2.2 — When precast members are incorporated R16.2.2 — The structural behavior of precast members may
into a structural system, the forces and deformations differ substantially from that of similar members that are
occurring in and adjacent to connections shall be cast-in-place. Design of connections to minimize or
included in the design. transmit forces due to shrinkage, creep, temperature change,
elastic deformation, differential settlement, wind, and earth-
quake require consideration in precast construction.
16.2.3 — Tolerances for both precast members and R16.2.3 — Design of precast members and connections is
interfacing members shall be specified. Design of particularly sensitive to tolerances on the dimensions of
precast members and connections shall include the individual members and on their location in the structure. To
effects of these tolerances. prevent misunderstanding, the tolerances used in design
should be specified in the contract documents. Instead of
specifying individual tolerances, the tolerance standard
assumed in design may be specified. It is important to specify
any deviations from accepted standards.
The tolerances required by 7.5 are considered to be a
minimum acceptable standard for reinforcement in precast
concrete. Refer to publications of the Precast/Prestressed
Concrete Institute (PCI) (References 16.9 through 16.11) for
guidance on industry-established standard product and erec-
tion tolerances. Added guidance is given in Reference 16.12.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
276 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
16.2.4 — In addition to the requirements for contract R16.2.4 — The additional requirements may be included in
documents in 1.2, (a) and (b) shall be included in either contract documents or shop drawings, depending on
either the contract documents or shop drawings: the assignment of responsibility for design.
(a) Details of reinforcement, inserts and lifting
devices required to resist temporary loads from
handling, storage, transportation, and erection;
(b) Required concrete strength at stated ages or
stages of construction.
16.3 — Distribution of forces among R16.3 — Distribution of forces among
members members
16.3.1 — Distribution of forces that are perpendicular R16.3.1 — Concentrated point and line loads can be distributed
to the plane of members shall be established by among members provided they have sufficient torsional
analysis or by test. stiffness and that shear can be transferred across joints.
Torsionally stiff members such as hollow-core or solid slabs
have more favorable load distribution properties than do
torsionally flexible members such as double tees with thin
flanges. The actual distribution of the load depends on many
factors discussed in detail in References 16.13 through
16.19. Large openings can cause significant changes in
distribution of forces.
16.3.2 — Where the system behavior requires in- R16.3.2 — In-plane forces result primarily from diaphragm
plane forces to be transferred between the members action in floors and roofs, causing tension or compression in
of a precast floor or wall system, 16.3.2.1 and 16.3.2.2 the chords and shear in the body of the diaphragm. A
shall apply. continuous path of steel, steel reinforcement, or both, using
lap splices, mechanical or welded splices, or mechanical
16.3.2.1 — In-plane force paths shall be continuous connectors, should be provided to carry the tension, whereas
through both connections and members. the shear and compression may be carried by the net
concrete section. A continuous path of steel through a
16.3.2.2 — Where tension forces occur, a contin- connection includes bolts, weld plates, headed studs, or
uous path of steel or steel reinforcement shall be other steel devices. Tension forces in the connections are to
provided. be transferred to the primary reinforcement in the members.
In-plane forces in precast wall systems result primarily from
diaphragm reactions and external lateral loads.
Connection details should provide for the forces and defor-
mations due to shrinkage, creep, and thermal effects.
Connection details may be selected to accommodate volume
changes and rotations caused by temperature gradients and
long-term deflections. When these effects are restrained,
connections and members should be designed to provide
adequate strength and ductility.
16.4 — Member design R16.4 — Member design
16.4.1 — In one-way precast floor and roof slabs and R16.4.1 — For prestressed concrete members not wider
in one-way precast, prestressed wall panels, all not than 12 ft, such as hollow-core slabs, solid slabs, or slabs
wider than 12 ft, and where members are not mechani- with closely spaced ribs, there is usually no need to provide
cally connected to cause restraint in the transverse transverse reinforcement to withstand shrinkage and
direction, the shrinkage and temperature reinforcement temperature stresses in the short direction. This is generally
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 277
CODE COMMENTARY
requirements of 7.12 in the direction normal to the flex- true also for nonprestressed floor and roof slabs. The 12 ft
ural reinforcement shall be permitted to be waived. width is less than that in which shrinkage and temperature
This waiver shall not apply to members that require stresses can build up to a magnitude requiring transverse
reinforcement to resist transverse flexural stresses. reinforcement. In addition, much of the shrinkage occurs
before the members are tied into the structure. Once in the
final structure, the members are usually not as rigidly
connected transversely as monolithic concrete, thus the
transverse restraint stresses due to both shrinkage and
temperature change are significantly reduced.
The waiver does not apply to members such as single and
double tees with thin, wide flanges.

16.5 — Structural integrity R16.5 — Structural integrity
16.5.1 — Except where the provisions of 16.5.2 R16.5.1 — The provisions of 7.13.3 apply to all precast
govern, the minimum provisions of 16.5.1.1 through concrete structures. Sections 16.5.1 and 16.5.2 give minimum
16.5.1.4 for structural integrity shall apply to all precast requirements to satisfy 7.13.3. It is not intended that these
concrete structures. minimum requirements override other applicable provisions
of the Code for design of precast concrete structures.
The overall integrity of a structure can be substantially
enhanced by minor changes in the amount, location, and
detailing of member reinforcement and in the detailing of
connection hardware.
16.5.1.1 — Longitudinal and transverse ties required R16.5.1.1 — Individual members may be connected into
by 7.13.3 shall connect members to a lateral load- a lateral load-resisting system by alternative methods. For
resisting system. example, a load-bearing spandrel could be connected to a
diaphragm (part of the lateral load-resisting system). Struc-
tural integrity could be achieved by connecting the spandrel
into all or a portion of the deck members forming the
diaphragm. Alternatively, the spandrel could be connected
only to its supporting columns, which in turn is connected to
the diaphragm.
16.5.1.2 — Where precast elements form floor or R16.5.1.2 — Diaphragms are typically provided as part
roof diaphragms, the connections between diaphragm of the lateral load-resisting system. The ties prescribed in
and those members being laterally supported shall 16.5.1.2 are the minimum required to attach members to the
have a nominal tensile strength capable of resisting floor or roof diaphragms.
not less than 300 lb per linear ft.
16.5.1.3 — Vertical tension tie requirements of R16.5.1.3 — Base connections and connections at
7.13.3 shall apply to all vertical structural members, horizontal joints in precast columns and wall panels,
except cladding, and shall be achieved by providing including shear walls, are designed to transfer all design

CODE COMMENTARY
connections at horizontal joints in accordance with forces and moments. The minimum tie requirements of
(a) through (c): 16.5.1.3 are not additive to these design requirements.
Common practice is to place the wall ties symmetrically
(a) Precast columns shall have a nominal strength in about the vertical centerline of the wall panel and within the
tension not less than 200A , in lb. For columns with outer quarters of the panel width, wherever possible.
g
a larger cross section than required by consideration
of loading, a reduced effective area A , based on

cross section required but not less than one-half the

(b) Precast wall panels shall have a minimum of two

less than 10,000 lb per tie;
(c) When design forces result in no tension at the
base, the ties required by 16.5.1.3(b) shall be
permitted to be anchored into an appropriately
reinforced concrete floor slab-on-ground.
16.5.1.4 — Connection details that rely solely on R16.5.1.4 — In the event of damage to a beam, it is
friction caused by gravity loads shall not be permitted. important that displacement of its supporting members be
minimized, so that other members will not lose their load-
carrying ability. This situation shows why connection
details that rely solely on friction caused by gravity loads
are not used. An exception could be heavy modular unit
structures (one or more cells in cell-type structures) where
resistance to overturning or sliding in any direction has a
large factor of safety. Acceptance of such systems should be
based on the provisions of 1.4.
16.5.2 — For precast concrete bearing wall structures R16.5.2 — The structural integrity minimum tie provisions
three or more stories in height, the minimum provi- for bearing wall structures, often called large panel structures,
sions of 16.5.2.1 through 16.5.2.5 shall apply. are intended to provide catenary hanger supports in case of
loss of a bearing wall support, as shown by test.16.21 Forces
induced by loading, temperature change, creep, and wind or
seismic action may require a larger amount of tie force. It is
intended that the general precast concrete provisions of
16.5.1 apply to bearing wall structures less than three stories
in height.
Minimum ties in structures three or more stories in height,
in accordance with 16.5.2.1, 16.5.2.2, 16.5.2.3, 16.5.2.4, and
16.5.2.5, are required for structural integrity (Fig. R16.5.2).
These provisions are based on PCI’s recommendations for
design of precast concrete bearing wall buildings.16.22 Tie
strength is based on yield strength.
16.5.2.1 — Longitudinal and transverse ties shall be R16.5.2.1 — Longitudinal ties may project from slabs
provided in floor and roof systems to provide a nominal and be lap spliced, welded, or mechanically connected, or
strength of 1500 lb per foot of width or length. Ties they may be embedded in grout joints, with sufficient length

Fig. R16.5.2—Typical arrangement of tensile ties in large

16.5.2.2 — Longitudinal ties parallel to floor or roof
slab spans shall be spaced not more than 10 ft on
centers. Provisions shall be made to transfer forces
around openings.
16.5.2.3 — Transverse ties perpendicular to floor or R16.5.2.3 — Transverse ties may be uniformly spaced
roof slab spans shall be spaced not greater than the either encased in the panels or in a topping, or they may be

and roof, within 4 ft of the edge, shall provide a additive with the longitudinal and transverse tie requirements.
nominal strength in tension not less than 16,000 lb.
16.5.2.5 — Vertical tension ties shall be provided in
all walls and shall be continuous over the height of the
building. They shall provide a nominal tensile strength
not less than 3000 lb per horizontal foot of wall. Not
less than two ties shall be provided for each precast
panel.
16.6 — Connection and bearing design R16.6 — Connection and bearing design
16.6.1 — Forces shall be permitted to be transferred R16.6.1 — The Code permits a variety of methods for
between members by grouted joints, shear keys, connecting members. These are intended for transfer of
mechanical connectors, reinforcing steel connections, forces both in-plane and perpendicular to the plane of the
reinforced topping, or a combination of these means. members.
16.6.1.1 — The adequacy of connections to transfer
forces between members shall be determined by
analysis or by test. Where shear is the primary result
of imposed loading, it shall be permitted to use the
provisions of 11.6 as applicable.
16.6.1.2 — When designing a connection using mate- R16.6.1.2 — Various components in a connection (such
rials with different structural properties, their relative stiff- as bolts, welds, plates, and inserts) have different properties
nesses, strengths, and ductilities shall be considered. that can affect the overall behavior of the connection.

16.7 — Items embedded after concrete R16.7 — Items embedded after concrete
placement placement
16.7.1 — When approved by the licensed design R16.7.1 — Section 16.7.1 is an exception to the provisions of
professional, embedded items (such as dowels or 7.5.1. Many precast products are manufactured in such a way
inserts) that either protrude from the concrete or that it is difficult, if not impossible, to position reinforcement
remain exposed for inspection shall be permitted to be that protrudes from the concrete before the concrete is placed.
embedded while the concrete is in a plastic state Such items as ties for horizontal shear and inserts can be
provided that 16.7.1.1, 16.7.1.2, and 16.7.1.3 are met. placed while the concrete is plastic, if proper precautions are
taken. This exception is not applicable to reinforcement that
16.7.1.1 — Embedded items are not required to be is completely embedded, or to embedded items that will be
hooked or tied to reinforcement within the concrete. hooked or tied to embedded reinforcement.
16.7.1.2 — Embedded items are maintained in the
correct position while the concrete remains plastic.
16.7.1.3 — The concrete is properly consolidated
around the embedded item.
16.8 — Marking and identification
16.8.1 — Each precast member shall be marked to
indicate its location and orientation in the structure and
date of manufacture.
16.8.2 — Identification marks shall correspond to
placing drawings.
16.9 — Handling R16.9 — Handling
16.9.1 — Member design shall consider forces and R16.9.1 — The Code requires acceptable performance at
distortions during curing, stripping, storage, transpor- service loads and adequate strength under factored loads.
tation, and erection so that precast members are not However, handling loads should not produce permanent
overstressed or otherwise damaged. stresses, strains, cracking, or deflections inconsistent with
the provisions of the Code. A precast member should not be
rejected for minor cracking or spalling where strength and
durability are not affected. Guidance on assessing cracks is
given in PCI reports on fabrication and shipment
cracks.16.24,16.25
16.9.2 — During erection, precast members and struc- R16.9.2 — All temporary erection connections, bracing,
tures shall be adequately supported and braced to shoring as well as the sequencing of removal of these items
ensure proper alignment and structural integrity until are shown on contract or erection drawings.
permanent connections are completed.
16.10 — Strength evaluation of precast R16.10 — Strength evaluation of precast
construction construction
16.10.1 — A precast element to be made composite The strength evaluation procedures of Chapter 20 are
with cast-in-place concrete shall be permitted to be applicable to precast members.
tested in flexure as a precast element alone in
accordance with 16.10.1.1 and 16.10.1.2.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
282 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
16.10.1.1 — Test loads shall be applied only when
calculations indicate the isolated precast element will
not be critical in compression or buckling.
16.10.1.2 — The test load shall be that load which,
when applied to the precast member alone, induces
the same total force in the tension reinforcement as
would be induced by loading the composite member
with the test load required by 20.3.2.
16.10.2 — The provisions of 20.5 shall be the basis for
acceptance or rejection of the precast element.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 283
CHAPTER 17 — COMPOSITE CONCRETE FLEXURAL MEMBERS
CODE COMMENTARY
17.1 — Scope R17.1 — Scope
17.1.1 — Provisions of Chapter 17 shall apply for R17.1.1 — The scope of Chapter 17 is intended to include
design of composite concrete flexural members defined all types of composite concrete flexural members. In some
as precast concrete, cast-in-place concrete elements, or cases with fully cast-in-place concrete, it may be necessary
both, constructed in separate placements but so inter- to design the interface of consecutive placements of
connected that all elements respond to loads as a unit. concrete as required for composite members. Composite
structural steel-concrete members are not covered in this
chapter. Design provisions for such composite members are
covered in Reference 17.1.
17.1.2 — All provisions of the Code shall apply to
composite concrete flexural members, except as
specifically modified in Chapter 17.
17.2 — General R17.2 — General
17.2.1 — The use of an entire composite member or
portions thereof for resisting shear and moment shall
be permitted.
17.2.2 — Individual elements shall be investigated for
all critical stages of loading.
17.2.3 — If the specified strength, unit weight, or other
properties of the various elements are different,
properties of the individual elements or the most
critical values shall be used in design.
17.2.4 — In strength computations of composite R17.2.4 — Tests have indicated that the strength of a
members, no distinction shall be made between composite member is the same whether or not the first element
shored and unshored members. cast is shored during casting and curing of the second element.
17.2.5 — All elements shall be designed to support all
loads introduced prior to full development of design
strength of composite members.
17.2.6 — Reinforcement shall be provided as required R17.2.6 — The extent of cracking is dependent on such
to minimize cracking and to prevent separation of factors as environment, aesthetics, and occupancy. In addition,
individual elements of composite members. composite action should not be impaired.
17.2.7 — Composite members shall meet requirements R17.2.7 — The premature loading of precast elements can
for control of deflections in accordance with 9.5.5. cause excessive creep and shrinkage deflections. This is
especially so at early ages when the moisture content is high
and the strength low.
The transfer of shear by direct bond is important if exces-
sive deflection from slippage is to be prevented. A shear key
is an added mechanical factor of safety but it does not
operate until slippage occurs.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
284 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
17.3 — Shoring R17.3 — Shoring
When used, shoring shall not be removed until The provisions of 9.5.5 cover the requirements pertaining to
supported elements have developed design properties deflections of shored and unshored members.
required to support all loads and limit deflections and
cracking at time of shoring removal.
17.4 — Vertical shear strength
17.4.1 — Where an entire composite member is
assumed to resist vertical shear, design shall be in
accordance with requirements of Chapter 11 as for a
monolithically cast member of the same cross-
sectional shape.
17.4.2 — Shear reinforcement shall be fully anchored
into interconnected elements in accordance with 12.13.
17.4.3 — Extended and anchored shear reinforcement
shall be permitted to be included as ties for horizontal
shear.
17.5 — Horizontal shear strength R17.5 — Horizontal shear strength
17.5.1 — In a composite member, full transfer of R17.5.1 — Full transfer of horizontal shear between segments
horizontal shear forces shall be ensured at contact of composite members should be ensured by horizontal shear
surfaces of interconnected elements. strength at contact surfaces or properly anchored ties, or both.
17.5.2 — For the provisions of 17.5, d shall be taken R17.5.2 — Prestressed members used in composite
as the distance from extreme compression fiber for construction may have variations in depth of tension reinforce-
entire composite section to centroid of prestressed ment along member length due to draped or depressed
and nonprestressed longitudinal tension reinforce- tendons. Because of this variation, the definition of d used in
ment, if any, but need not be taken less than 0.80h for Chapter 11 for determination of vertical shear strength is
prestressed concrete members. also appropriate when determining horizontal shear strength.

17.5.4 — As an alternative to 17.5.3, horizontal shear
shall be permitted to be determined by computing the
actual change in compressive or tensile force in any
segment, and provisions shall be made to transfer that
force as horizontal shear to the supporting element.

u
exceed horizontal shear strength φV as given in
nh
17.5.3.1 through 17.5.3.4, where area of contact

v
17.5.4.1 — Where ties provided to resist horizontal R17.5.4.1 — The distribution of horizontal shear stresses
shear are designed to satisfy 17.5.4, the tie area to tie along the contact surface in a composite member will reflect
spacing ratio along the member shall approximately the distribution of shear along the member. Horizontal shear
reflect the distribution of shear forces in the member. failure will initiate where the horizontal shear stress is a
maximum and will spread to regions of lower stress.
Because the slip at peak horizontal shear resistance is small
for a concrete-to-concrete contact surface, longitudinal
redistribution of horizontal shear resistance is very limited.
The spacing of the ties along the contact surface should,
therefore, be such as to provide horizontal shear resistance
distributed approximately as the shear acting on the member
is distributed.
17.5.5 — Where tension exists across any contact R17.5.5 — Proper anchorage of ties extending across inter-
surface between interconnected elements, shear faces is required to maintain contact of the interfaces.
transfer by contact shall be permitted only when
minimum ties are provided in accordance with 17.6.
17.6 — Ties for horizontal shear R17.6 — Ties for horizontal shear
17.6.1 — Where ties are provided to transfer hori- The minimum areas and maximum spacings are based on
zontal shear, tie area shall not be less than that test data given in References 17.2 through 17.6.
required by 11.4.6.3, and tie spacing shall not exceed
four times the least dimension of supported element,
nor exceed 24 in.
17.6.2 — Ties for horizontal shear shall consist of
single bars or wire, multiple leg stirrups, or vertical
legs of welded wire reinforcement.
17.6.3 — All ties shall be fully anchored into intercon-
nected elements in accordance with 12.13.

STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 287
CHAPTER 18 — PRESTRESSED CONCRETE
CODE COMMENTARY
18.1 — Scope R18.1 — Scope
18.1.1 — Provisions of Chapter 18 shall apply to R18.1.1 — The provisions of Chapter 18 were developed
members prestressed with wire, strands, or bars primarily for structural members such as slabs, beams, and
conforming to provisions for prestressing steel in 3.5.6. columns that are commonly used in buildings. Many of the
provisions may be applied to other types of construction,
such as pressure vessels, pavements, pipes, and crossties.
Application of the provisions is left to the judgment of the
licensed design professional in cases not specifically cited
in the Code.
18.1.2 — All provisions of this Code not specifically
excluded, and not in conflict with provisions of Chapter 18,
shall apply to prestressed concrete.
18.1.3 — The following provisions of this Code shall R18.1.3 — Some sections of the Code are excluded from
not apply to prestressed concrete, except as specifi- use in the design of prestressed concrete for specific
cally noted: Sections 6.4.4, 7.6.5, 8.12.2, 8.12.3, reasons. The following discussion provides explanation for
8.12.4, 8.13, 10.5, 10.6, 10.9.1, and 10.9.2; Chapter 13; such exclusions:
and Sections 14.3, 14.5, and 14.6, except that certain
sections of 10.6 apply as noted in 18.4.4. Section 6.4.4 — Tendons of continuous post-tensioned
beams and slabs are usually stressed at a point along the
span where the tendon profile is at or near the centroid of
the concrete cross section. Therefore, interior construction
joints are usually located within the end thirds of the span,
rather than the middle third of the span as required by 6.4.4.
Construction joints located as described in continuous post-
tensioned beams and slabs have a long history of satisfactory
performance. Thus, 6.4.4 is excluded from application to
prestressed concrete.
Section 7.6.5 — Section 7.6.5 of the Code is excluded from
application to prestressed concrete because the requirements
for bonded reinforcement and unbonded tendons for cast-in-
place members are provided in 18.9 and 18.12, respectively.
Sections 8.12.2, 8.12.3, and 8.12.4 — The empirical
provisions of 8.12.2, 8.12.3, and 8.12.4 for T-beams were
developed for nonprestressed reinforced concrete, and if
applied to prestressed concrete would exclude many standard
prestressed products in satisfactory use today. Hence, proof
by experience permits variations.
By excluding 8.12.2, 8.12.3, and 8.12.4, no special require-
ments for prestressed concrete T-beams appear in the Code.
Instead, the determination of an effective width of flange is left
to the experience and judgment of the licensed design
professional. Where possible, the flange widths in 8.12.2,
8.12.3, and 8.12.4 should be used unless experience has
proven that variations are safe and satisfactory. It is not neces-
sarily conservative in elastic analysis and design considerations
to use the maximum flange width as permitted in 8.12.2.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
288 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
Sections 8.12.1 and 8.12.5 provide general requirements for
T-beams that are also applicable to prestressed concrete
members. The spacing limitations for slab reinforcement are
based on flange thickness, which for tapered flanges can be
taken as the average thickness.
Section 8.13 — The empirical limits established for
nonprestressed reinforced concrete joist floors are based on
successful past performance of joist construction using
standard joist forming systems. See R8.13. For prestressed
joist construction, experience and judgment should be used.
The provisions of 8.13 may be used as a guide.
Sections 10.5, 10.9.1, and 10.9.2 — For prestressed
concrete, the limitations on reinforcement given in 10.5,
10.9.1, and 10.9.2 are replaced by those in 18.8.3, 18.9, and
18.11.2.
Section 10.6 —This section does not apply to prestressed
members in its entirety. However, 10.6.4 and 10.6.7 are
referenced in 18.4.4 pertaining to Class C prestressed flexural
members.
Chapter 13 — The design of continuous prestressed concrete
slabs requires recognition of secondary moments. Also,
volume changes due to the prestressing force can create addi-
tional loads on the structure that are not adequately covered in
Chapter 13. Because of these unique properties associated
with prestressing, many of the design procedures of Chapter
13 are not appropriate for prestressed concrete structures and
are replaced by the provisions of 18.12.
Sections 14.5 and 14.6 — The requirements for wall design
in 14.5 and 14.6 are largely empirical, utilizing consider-
ations not intended to apply to prestressed concrete.
18.2 — General R18.2 — General
18.2.1 — Prestressed members shall meet the R18.2.1 and R18.2.2 — The design investigation should
strength requirements of this Code. include all stages that may be significant. The three major
stages are: (1) jacking stage, or prestress transfer stage—
18.2.2 — Design of prestressed members shall be when the tensile force in the prestressing steel is transferred
based on strength and on behavior at service condi- to the concrete and stress levels may be high relative to
tions at all stages that will be critical during the life of concrete strength; (2) service load stage—after long-term
the structure from the time prestress is first applied. volume changes have occurred; and (3) the factored load
stage—when the strength of the member is checked. There
may be other load stages that require investigation. For
example, if the cracking load is significant, this load stage
may require study, or the handling and transporting stage
may be critical.
From the standpoint of satisfactory behavior, the two
stages of most importance are those for service load and
factored load.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 289
CODE COMMENTARY
Service load stage refers to the loads defined in the general
building code (without load factors), such as live load and
dead load, while the factored load stage refers to loads
multiplied by the appropriate load factors.
Section 18.3.2 provides assumptions that may be used for
investigation at service loads and after transfer of the
prestressing force.
18.2.3 — Stress concentrations due to prestressing
shall be considered in design.
18.2.4 — Provisions shall be made for effects on
adjoining construction of elastic and plastic deforma-
tions, deflections, changes in length, and rotations due
to prestressing. Effects of temperature and shrinkage
shall also be included.
18.2.5 — The possibility of buckling in a member R18.2.5 — Section 18.2.5 refers to the type of post-
between points where there is intermittent contact tensioning where the prestressing steel makes intermittent
between the prestressing steel and an oversize duct, contact with an oversize duct. Precautions should be taken
and buckling in thin webs and flanges shall be to prevent buckling of such members.
considered.
If the prestressing steel is in complete contact with the
member being prestressed, or is unbonded with the
sheathing not excessively larger than the prestressing steel,
it is not possible to buckle the member under the
prestressing force being introduced.
18.2.6 — In computing section properties before R18.2.6 — In considering the area of the open ducts, the
bonding of prestressing steel, effect of loss of area due critical sections should include those that have coupler
to open ducts shall be considered. sheaths that may be of a larger size than the duct containing
the prestressing steel. Also, in some instances, the trumpet
or transition piece from the conduit to the anchorage may be
of such a size as to create a critical section. If the effect of
the open duct area on design is deemed negligible, section
properties may be based on total area.
In post-tensioned members after grouting and in pretensioned
members, section properties may be based on effective
sections using transformed areas of bonded prestressing
steel and nonprestressed reinforcement gross sections, or
net sections.
18.3 — Design assumptions R18.3 — Design assumptions
18.3.1 — Strength design of prestressed members for
flexure and axial loads shall be based on assumptions
given in 10.2, except that 10.2.4 shall apply only to
reinforcement conforming to 3.5.3.
18.3.2 — For investigation of stresses at transfer of
prestress, at service loads, and at cracking loads,
elastic theory shall be used with the assumptions of
18.3.2.1 and 18.3.2.2.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
290 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
18.3.2.1 — Strains vary linearly with depth through
the entire load range.
18.3.2.2 — At cracked sections, concrete resists no
tension.

These classes apply to both bonded and unbonded

t c prestressed flexural members, but prestressed two-way slab
systems must be designed as Class U.
The precompressed tensile zone is that portion of a
prestressed member where flexural tension, calculated using
gross section properties, would occur under unfactored dead
and live loads if the prestress force was not present.
Prestressed concrete is usually designed so that the prestress
force introduces compression into this zone, thus effectively
reducing the magnitude of the tensile stress.
18.3.4 — For Class U and Class T flexural members, R18.3.4 — A method for computing stresses in a cracked
stresses at service loads shall be permitted to be section is given in Reference 18.1.
calculated using the uncracked section. For Class C
flexural members, stresses at service loads shall be
calculated using the cracked transformed section.

shall be calculated in accordance with 9.5.4. computing deflections of cracked members.
18.4 — Serviceability requirements — R18.4 — Serviceability requirements —
Flexural members Flexural members
Permissible stresses in concrete address serviceability.
Permissible stresses do not ensure adequate structural
strength, which should be checked in conformance with
other Code requirements.

Designs with transient live loads that are large compared to
sustained live and dead loads have been penalized by the
previous single compression stress limit. Therefore, the
stress limit of 0.60f′ permits a one-third increase in allowable
c
compression stress for members subject to transient loads.
Sustained live load is any portion of the service live load
that will be sustained for a sufficient period to cause signifi-
cant time-dependent deflections. Thus, when the sustained
live and dead loads are a large percentage of total service
load, the 0.45f′ limit of 18.4.2(a) may control. On the other
c
hand, when a large portion of the total service load consists
of a transient or temporary service live load, the increased
stress limit of 18.4.2(b) may apply.
The compression limit of 0.45f′ for prestress plus sustained
c
loads will continue to control the long-term behavior of
prestressed members.

18.5 — Permissible stresses in prestressing R18.5 — Permissible stresses in prestressing
steel steel
The Code does not distinguish between temporary and
effective prestressing steel stresses. Only one limit on
prestressing steel stress is provided because the initial
prestressing steel stress (immediately after transfer) can
prevail for a considerable time, even after the structure has
been put into service. This stress, therefore, should have an
adequate safety factor under service conditions and cannot
be considered as a temporary stress. Any subsequent
decrease in prestressing steel stress due to losses can only
improve conditions and no limit on such stress decrease is
provided in the Code.
18.5.1 — Tensile stress in prestressing steel shall not R18.5.1 — Because of the high yield strength of low-
exceed the following: relaxation wire and strand meeting the requirements of ASTM
A421 and A416, it is appropriate to specify permissible
(a) Due to prestressing steel jacking force...... 0.94f py stresses in terms of specified minimum ASTM yield strength
along with the specified minimum ASTM tensile strength.
but not greater than the lesser of 0.80f and the
pu
maximum value recommended by the manufacturer Because of the higher allowable initial prestressing steel
of prestressing steel or anchorage devices. stresses permitted since the 1983 Code, final stresses can be
greater. Structures subject to corrosive conditions or

repeated loadings should be of concern when setting a limit

18.6 — Loss of prestress R18.6 — Loss of prestress
18.6.1 — To determine effective stress in the R18.6.1 — For an explanation of how to compute prestress
prestressing steel, f , allowance for the following losses, see References 18.6 through 18.9. Lump sum values
se
sources of loss of prestress shall be considered: of prestress losses for both pretensioned and post-tensioned
members that were indicated before the 1983 Commentary
(a) Prestressing steel seating at transfer; are considered obsolete. Reasonably accurate estimates of
prestress losses can be calculated in accordance with the
(b) Elastic shortening of concrete;
recommendations in Reference 18.9, which include consider-
ation of initial stress level (0.7f or higher), type of steel
(c) Creep of concrete; pu
(stress-relieved or low-relaxation wire, strand, or bar), exposure
(d) Shrinkage of concrete; conditions, and type of construction (pretensioned, bonded
post-tensioned, or unbonded post-tensioned).
(e) Relaxation of prestressing steel stress;
Actual losses, greater or smaller than the computed values,
(f) Friction loss due to intended or unintended
have little effect on the design strength of the member, but
curvature in post-tensioning tendons.
affect service load behavior (deflections, camber, cracking
load) and connections. At service loads, overestimation of
prestress losses can be almost as detrimental as underestima-
tion, since the former can result in excessive camber and
horizontal movement.
18.6.2 — Friction loss in post-tensioning tendons R18.6.2 — Friction loss in post-tensioning tendons
18.6.2.1 — The required effective prestress force Estimation of friction losses in post-tensioned tendons is
shall be indicated in the contract documents. addressed in Reference 18.10. Values of the wobble and
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
294 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
18.6.2.2 — Computed friction loss shall be based on curvature friction coefficients to be used for the particular
experimentally determined wobble and curvature friction types of prestressing steel and particular types of ducts
coefficients. should be obtained from the manufacturers of the tendons.
An unrealistically low estimate of the friction loss can lead
18.6.2.3 — The prestress force and friction losses to improper camber, or potential deflection, of the member
shall be verified during tendon stressing operations as and inadequate prestress. Overestimation of the friction may
specified in18.20. result in extra prestressing force. This could lead to exces-
sive camber and excessive shortening of a member. If the
friction factors are determined to be less than those assumed
in the design, the tendon stressing should be adjusted to give
only that prestressing force in the critical portions of the
structure required by the design.
When the safety or serviceability of the structure may be
involved, the acceptable range of prestressing steel jacking
forces or other limiting requirements should either be given
or approved by the licensed design professional in confor-
mance with the permissible stresses of 18.4 and 18.5.
18.6.3 — Where loss of prestress in a member occurs
due to connection of the member to adjoining
construction, such loss of prestress shall be allowed
for in design.
18.7 — Flexural strength R18.7 — Flexural strength
18.7.1 — Design moment strength of flexural R18.7.1 — Design moment strength of prestressed flexural
members shall be computed by the strength design members may be computed using strength equations similar
methods of the Code. For prestressing steel, f shall to those for nonprestressed concrete members. The 1983
ps
be substituted for f in strength computations. Code provided strength equations for rectangular and
y
flanged sections, with tension reinforcement only and with
tension and compression reinforcement. When part of the
prestressing steel is in the compression zone, a method
based on applicable conditions of equilibrium and compati-
bility of strains at a factored load condition should be used.
For other cross sections, the design moment strength φM is
n
computed by an analysis based on stress and strain
compatibility, using the stress-strain properties of the
prestressing steel and the assumptions given in 10.2.

unbonded tendons and span-to-depth ratios greater than 35
the lesser of f and (f + 30,000).
py se (one-way slabs, flat plates, and flat slabs).18.11 These tests also
indicate that Eq. (18-2), formerly used for all span-depth ratios,
overestimates the amount of stress increase in such members.
Although these same tests indicate that the moment strength of
those shallow members designed using Eq. (18-2) meets the
factored load strength requirements, this reflects the effect of
the Code requirements for minimum bonded reinforcement, as
well as the limitation on concrete tensile stress that often
controls the amount of prestressing force provided.
18.7.3 — Nonprestressed reinforcement conforming to
3.5.3, if used with prestressing steel, shall be permitted
to be considered to contribute to the tensile force and
to be included in moment strength computations at a
stress equal to f . Other nonprestressed reinforcement
y
shall be permitted to be included in strength computa-
tions only if a strain compatibility analysis is performed
to determine stresses in such reinforcement.

18.8.2 — Total amount of prestressed and nonpre- R18.8.2 — This provision is a precaution against abrupt
stressed reinforcement in members with bonded flexural failure developing immediately after cracking. A
prestressed reinforcement shall be adequate to flexural member designed according to Code provisions
develop a factored load at least 1.2 times the cracking requires considerable additional load beyond cracking to
load computed on the basis of the modulus of rupture reach its flexural strength. Thus, considerable deflection
f specified in 9.5.2.3. This provision shall be permitted would warn that the member strength is approaching. If the
r
to be waived for flexural members with shear and flexural strength were reached shortly after cracking, the
flexural strength at least twice that required by 9.2. warning deflection would not occur. Transfer of force between
the concrete and the prestressing steel, and abrupt flexural
failure immediately after cracking, does not occur when the
prestressing steel is unbonded18.12; therefore, this requirement
does not apply to members with unbonded tendons.
18.8.3 — Part or all of the bonded reinforcement R18.8.3 — Some bonded steel is required to be placed near
consisting of bars or tendons shall be provided as close the tension face of prestressed flexural members. The
as practicable to the tension face in prestressed flexural purpose of this bonded steel is to control cracking under full
members. In members prestressed with unbonded service loads or overloads.
tendons, the minimum bonded reinforcement consisting
of bars or tendons shall be as required by 18.9.
18.9 — Minimum bonded reinforcement R18.9 — Minimum bonded reinforcement
18.9.1 — A minimum area of bonded reinforcement R18.9.1 — Some bonded reinforcement is required by the
shall be provided in all flexural members with unbonded Code in members prestressed with unbonded tendons to ensure
tendons as required by 18.9.2 and 18.9.3. flexural performance at ultimate member strength, rather than
as a tied arch, and to limit crack width and spacing at service
load when concrete tensile stresses exceed the modulus of
rupture. Providing the minimum bonded reinforcement as
stipulated in 18.9 helps to ensure adequate performance.
Research has shown that unbonded post-tensioned members
do not inherently provide large capacity for energy dissipation
under severe earthquake loadings because the member
response is primarily elastic. For this reason, unbonded
post-tensioned structural elements reinforced in accordance
with the provisions of this section should be assumed to
carry only vertical loads and to act as horizontal diaphragms
between energy dissipating elements under earthquake load-
ings of the magnitude defined in 21.1.1. The minimum
bonded reinforcement areas required by Eq. (18-4) and (18-6)
are absolute minimum areas independent of grade of steel or
design yield strength.

18.10 — Statically indeterminate structures R18.10 — Statically indeterminate structures
18.10.1 — Frames and continuous construction of
prestressed concrete shall be designed for satisfactory
performance at service load conditions and for
adequate strength.
18.10.2 — Performance at service load conditions
shall be determined by elastic analysis, considering
reactions, moments, shears, and axial forces induced
by prestressing, creep, shrinkage, temperature
change, axial deformation, restraint of attached structural
elements, and foundation settlement.
18.10.3 — Moments used to compute required R18.10.3 — For statically indeterminate structures, the
strength shall be the sum of the moments due to moments due to reactions induced by prestressing forces,
reactions induced by prestressing (with a load factor of referred to as secondary moments, are significant in both the
1.0) and the moments due to factored loads. Adjust- elastic and inelastic states (see References 18.20 through
ment of the sum of these moments shall be permitted 18.22). The elastic deformations caused by a nonconcordant
as allowed in 18.10.4. tendon change the amount of inelastic rotation required to
obtain a given amount of moment redistribution. Conversely,
for a beam with a given inelastic rotational capacity, the
amount by which the moment at the support may be varied
is changed by an amount equal to the secondary moment at
the support due to prestressing. Thus, the Code requires that
secondary moments be included in determining design
moments.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 299
CODE COMMENTARY
To determine the moments used in design, the order of
calculation should be: (a) determine moments due to dead
and live load; (b) modify by algebraic addition of secondary
moments; (c) redistribute as permitted. A positive secondary
moment at the support caused by a tendon transformed
downward from a concordant profile will reduce the negative
moments near the supports and increase the positive
moments in the midspan regions. A tendon that is transformed
upward will have the reverse effect.
18.10.4 — Redistribution of moments in continuous R18.10.4 — Redistribution of moments in continuous
prestressed flexural members prestressed flexural members
18.10.4.1 — Where bonded reinforcement is The provisions for redistribution of moments given in 8.4
provided at supports in accordance with 18.9, it shall apply equally to prestressed members. See Reference 18.23
be permitted to decrease negative or positive for a comparison of research results and to Section 18.10.4
moments calculated by elastic theory for any assumed of the 1999 Code.
loading, in accordance with 8.4.
For the moment redistribution principles of 18.10.4 to be
18.10.4.2 — The reduced moment shall be used for applicable to beams with unbonded tendons, it is necessary
calculating redistributed moments at all other sections that such beams contain sufficient bonded reinforcement to
within the spans. Static equilibrium shall be main- ensure they will act as beams after cracking and not as a
tained after redistribution of moments for each loading series of tied arches. The minimum bonded reinforcement
arrangement. requirements of 18.9 serves this purpose.
18.11 — Compression members — R18.11 — Compression members —
Combined flexure and axial loads Combined flexure and axial loads
18.11.1 — Prestressed concrete members subject to
combined flexure and axial load, with or without
nonprestressed reinforcement, shall be proportioned
by the strength design methods of this Code. Effects of
prestress, creep, shrinkage, and temperature change
shall be included.
18.11.2 — Limits for reinforcement of prestressed R18.11.2 — Limits for reinforcement of prestressed
compression members compression members
18.11.2.1 — Members with average compressive
stress in concrete less than 225 psi, due to effective
prestress force only, shall have minimum reinforce-
ment in accordance with 7.10, 10.9.1 and 10.9.2 for
columns, or 14.3 for walls.
18.11.2.2 — Except for walls, members with average
compressive stress in concrete, due to effective
prestress force only, equal to or greater than 225 psi,
shall have all tendons enclosed by spirals or transverse
ties in accordance with (a) through (d):
(a) Spirals shall conform to 7.10.4;
(b) Transverse ties shall be at least No. 3 in size or
welded wire reinforcement of equivalent area, and
shall be spaced vertically not to exceed 48 tie bar or
wire diameters, or the least dimension of the
compression member;
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
300 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
(c) Ties shall be located vertically not more than half
a tie spacing above top of footing or slab in any
story, and not more than half a tie spacing below the
lowest horizontal reinforcement in members
supported above;
(d) Where beams or brackets frame into all sides of a
column, ties shall be terminated not more than 3 in.
below lowest reinforcement in such beams or brackets.
18.11.2.3 — For walls with average compressive R18.11.2.3 — The minimum amounts of reinforcement in
stress in concrete due to effective prestress force only 14.3 need not apply to prestressed concrete walls, provided
equal to or greater than 225 psi, minimum reinforce- the average compressive stress in concrete due to effective
ment required by 14.3 shall not apply where structural prestress force only is 225 psi or greater and a structural
analysis shows adequate strength and stability. analysis is performed to show adequate strength and
stability with lower amounts of reinforcement.
18.12 — Slab systems R18.12 — Slab systems
18.12.1 — Factored moments and shears in R18.12.1 — Use of the equivalent frame method of analysis
prestressed slab systems reinforced for flexure in (see 13.7) or more precise analysis procedures is required
more than one direction shall be determined in accor- for determination of both service and factored moments and
dance with provisions of 13.7 (excluding 13.7.7.4 and shears for prestressed slab systems. The equivalent frame
13.7.7.5), or by more detailed design procedures. method of analysis has been shown by tests of large structural
models to satisfactorily predict factored moments and
shears in prestressed slab systems. (See References 18.15
through 18.17, and 18.24 through 18.26.) The referenced
research also shows that analysis using prismatic sections or
other approximations of stiffness may provide erroneous
results on the unsafe side. Section 13.7.7.4 is excluded from
application to prestressed slab systems because it relates to
reinforced slabs designed by the direct design method, and
because moment redistribution for prestressed slabs is
covered in 18.10.4. Section 13.7.7.5 does not apply to
prestressed slab systems because the distribution of
moments between column strips and middle strips required
by 13.7.7.5 is based on tests for nonprestressed concrete
slabs. Simplified methods of analysis using average coeffi-
cients do not apply to prestressed concrete slab systems.

ability limitations, including limits on deflections, shall more spans in each direction, the span-thickness ratio generally
be met, with appropriate consideration of the factors should not exceed 42 for floors and 48 for roofs; these limits
listed in 18.10.2. may be increased to 48 and 52, respectively, if calculations
verify that both short- and long-term deflection, camber, and
vibration frequency and amplitude are not objectionable.

computed and checked against the requirements of service-
ability of the structure.

CODE COMMENTARY
The maximum length of a slab between construction joints
is generally limited to 100 to 150 ft to minimize the effects
of slab shortening, and to avoid excessive loss of prestress
due to friction.

18.13 — Post-tensioned tendon anchorage R18.13 — Post-tensioned tendon anchorage
zones zones
Section 18.13 was extensively revised in the 1999 Code and
was made compatible with the 1996 AASHTO “Standard
Specifications for Highway Bridges”18.28 and the recom-
mendations of NCHRP Report 356.18.29
Following the adoption by AASHTO 1994 of comprehensive
provisions for post-tensioned anchorage zones, ACI
Committee 318 revised the Code to be generally consistent
with the AASHTO requirements. Thus, the highly detailed
AASHTO provisions for analysis and reinforcement
detailing are deemed to satisfy the more general ACI 318
requirements. In the specific areas of anchorage device
evaluation and acceptance testing, ACI 318 incorporates the
detailed AASHTO provisions by reference.
18.13.1 — Anchorage zone R18.13.1 — Anchorage zone
The anchorage zone shall be considered as composed Based on the Principle of Saint-Venant, the extent of the
of two zones: anchorage zone may be estimated as approximately equal to
the largest dimension of the cross section. Local zones and
(a) The local zone is the rectangular prism (or equiva- general zones are shown in Fig. R18.13.1(a). When anchorage
lent rectangular prism for circular or oval anchorages) devices located away from the end of the member are tensioned,
of concrete immediately surrounding the anchorage large tensile stresses exist locally behind and ahead of the
device and any confining reinforcement; device. These tensile stresses are induced by incompatibility
of deformations ahead of [as shown in Fig. R.18.13.1(b)] and
(b) The general zone is the anchorage zone as
behind the anchorage device. The entire shaded region
defined in 2.2 and includes the local zone.
should be considered, as shown in Fig. R18.13.1(b).

18.13.2 — Local zone R18.13.2 — Local zone
18.13.2.1 — Design of local zones shall be based The local zone resists the very high local stresses introduced
upon the factored prestressing force, P , and the by the anchorage device and transfers them to the remainder
pu
requirements of 9.2.5 and 9.3.2.5. of the anchorage zone. The behavior of the local zone is
strongly influenced by the specific characteristics of the
18.13.2.2 — Local-zone reinforcement shall be anchorage device and its confining reinforcement, and less
provided where required for proper functioning of the influenced by the geometry and loading of the overall
anchorage device. structure. Local-zone design sometimes cannot be
completed until specific anchorage devices are determined
18.13.2.3 — Local-zone requirements of 18.13.2.2 at the shop drawing stage. When special anchorage devices
are satisfied by 18.14.1 or 18.15.1 and 18.15.2. are used, the anchorage device supplier should furnish the
test information to show the device is satisfactory under
AASHTO “Standard Specifications for Highway Bridges,”
Division II, Article 10.3.2.3 and provide information
regarding necessary conditions for use of the device. The
main considerations in local-zone design are the effects of
the high bearing pressure and the adequacy of any confining
reinforcement provided to increase the capacity of the
concrete resisting bearing stresses.
The factored prestressing force P is the product of the
pu
load factor (1.2 from Section 9.2.7) and the maximum
prestressing force allowed. Under 18.5.1, this is usually
overstressing due to 0.94f , but not greater than 0.8f ,
py pu
which is permitted for short periods of time.

anc
anchorage device or group of closely spaced

Anchorage devices should be treated as closely spaced if
their center-to-center spacing does not exceed 1.5 times the
width of the anchorage device in the direction considered.
The spalling force for tendons for which the centroid lies
within the kern of the section may be estimated as 2 percent
of the total factored prestressing force, except for multiple
anchorage devices with center-to-center spacing greater
than 0.4 times the depth of the section. For large spacings
and for cases where the centroid of the tendons is located
outside the kern, a detailed analysis is required. In addition,
in the post-tensioning of thin sections, or flanged sections, or
irregular sections, or when the tendons have appreciable
curvature within the general zone, more general procedures
such as those of AASHTO Articles 9.21.4 and 9.21.5 will be
required. Detailed recommendations for design principles
that apply to all design methods are given in Article 9.21.3.4
of Reference 18.28.
18.13.5.3 — The stressing sequence shall be specified R18.13.5.3 — The sequence of anchorage device
in the contract documents and considered in the design. stressing can have a significant effect on the general zone
stresses. Therefore, it is important to consider not only the
final stage of a stressing sequence with all tendons stressed,
but also intermediate stages during construction. The most
critical bursting forces caused by each of the sequentially
post-tensioned tendon combinations, as well as that of the
entire group of tendons, should be taken into account.
Fig. R18.13.5—Strut-and-tie model example.

18.13.5.4 — Three-dimensional effects shall be R18.13.5.4 — The provision for three-dimensional
considered in design and analyzed using three-dimen- effects was included so that the effects perpendicular to the
sional procedures or approximated by considering the main plane of the member, such as bursting forces in the
summation of effects for two orthogonal planes. thin direction of webs or slabs are not neglected. In many
cases these effects can be determined independently for
each direction, but some applications require a fully three-
dimensional analysis (for example, diaphragms for the
anchorage of external tendons).
18.13.5.5 — For anchorage devices located away R18.13.5.5 — Where anchorages are located away from
from the end of the member, bonded reinforcement the end of a member, local tensile stresses are generated
shall be provided to transfer at least 0.35P into the behind these anchorages (see Fig. R18.13.1(b)) due to

pu
prestressing force being resisted by reinforcement at 0.6f .
y
18.13.5.6 — Where tendons are curved in the
general zone, except for monostrand tendons in slabs
or where analysis shows reinforcement is not required,
bonded reinforcement shall be provided to resist radial
and splitting forces.
18.13.5.7 — Except for monostrand tendons in slabs
or where analysis shows reinforcement is not required,
minimum reinforcement with a nominal tensile strength
equal to 2 percent of each factored prestressing force
shall be provided in orthogonal directions parallel to
the back face of all anchorage zones to limit spalling.
18.13.5.8 — Tensile strength of concrete shall be
neglected in calculations of reinforcement requirements.
18.13.6 — Detailing requirements
Selection of reinforcement sizes, spacings, cover, and
other details for anchorage zones shall make allowances
for tolerances on the bending, fabrication, and place-
ment of reinforcement, for the size of aggregate, and
for adequate placement and consolidation of the
concrete.

diameter bar tendons diameter bar tendons
18.14.1 — Local zone design
Monostrand or single 5/8 in. or smaller diameter bar
anchorage devices and local zone reinforcement shall
meet the requirements of ACI 423.7 or the special
anchorage device requirements of 18.15.2.

18.14.3 — General-zone design for groups of R18.14.3 — General-zone design for groups of
monostrand tendons in beams and girders monostrand tendons in beams and girders
Design of general zones for groups of monostrand Groups of monostrand tendons with individual monostrand
tendons in beams and girders shall meet the require- anchorage devices are often used in beams and girders.
ments of 18.13.3 through 18.13.5. Anchorage devices can be treated as closely spaced if their
center-to-center spacing does not exceed 1.5 times the width
of the anchorage device in the direction considered. If a
beam or girder has a single anchorage device or a single
group of closely spaced anchorage devices, the use of
simplified equations such as those given in R18.13.5 is
allowed, unless 18.13.5.2 governs. More complex conditions
can be designed using strut-and-tie models. Detailed
recommendations for use of such models are given in
References 18.27 and 18.30 as well as in R18.13.5.

meet the requirements of 18.13.3 through 18.13.5.
18.16 — Corrosion protection for R18.16 — Corrosion protection for
unbonded tendons unbonded tendons
18.16.1 — Unbonded prestressing steel shall be R18.16.1 — Suitable material for corrosion protection of
encased with sheathing. The prestressing steel shall unbonded prestressting steel should have the properties
be completely coated and the sheathing around the identified in Section 5.1 of Reference 18.30.
prestressing steel filled with suitable material to
inhibit corrosion.
18.16.2 — Sheathing shall be watertight and contin- R18.16.2 — Typically, sheathing is a continuous, seamless,
uous over entire length to be unbonded. high-density polythylene material that is extruded directly
onto the coated prestressing steel.
18.16.3 — For applications in corrosive environments,
the sheathing shall be connected to all stressing, inter-
mediate and fixed anchorages in a watertight fashion.
18.16.4 — Unbonded single-strand tendons shall be R18.16.4 — In the 1989 Code, corrosion protection require-
protected against corrosion in accordance with ACI ments for unbonded single-strand tendons were added in
423.7. accordance with the Post-Tensioning Institute’s “Specifica-
tion for Unbonded Single Strand Tendons.” In the 2002
Code, the reference changed to ACI 423.6. In the 2008
Code, the reference was changed to ACI 423.7.

310 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
18.17 — Post-tensioning ducts R18.17 — Post-tensioning ducts
18.17.1 — Ducts for grouted tendons shall be mortar-
tight and nonreactive with concrete, prestressing steel,
grout, and corrosion inhibitor.
18.17.2 — Ducts for grouted single-wire, single-strand,
or single-bar tendons shall have an inside diameter at
least 1/4 in. larger than the prestressing steel diameter.
18.17.3 — Ducts for grouted multiple wire, multiple
strand, or multiple bar tendons shall have an inside
cross-sectional area at least two times the cross-
sectional area of the prestressing steel.
18.17.4 — Ducts shall be maintained free of ponded R18.17.4 — Water in ducts may cause distress to the
water if members to be grouted are exposed to surrounding concrete upon freezing. When strands are present,
temperatures below freezing prior to grouting. ponded water in ducts should also be avoided. A corrosion
inhibitor should be used to provide temporary corrosion
protection if prestressing steel is exposed to prolonged periods
of moisture in the ducts before grouting.18.31
18.18 — Grout for bonded tendons R18.18 — Grout for bonded tendons
18.18.1 — Grout shall consist of portland cement and Proper grout and grouting procedures are critical to post-
water; or portland cement, sand, and water. tensioned construction.18.32,18.33 Grout provides bond
between the prestressing steel and the duct, and provides
corrosion protection to the prestressing steel.
Past success with grout for bonded tendons has been with
portland cement. A blanket endorsement of all cementitious
materials (defined in 2.1) for use with this grout is deemed
inappropriate because of a lack of experience or tests with
cementitious materials other than portland cement and a
concern that some cementitious materials might introduce
chemicals listed as harmful to tendons in R18.18.2. Thus,
portland cement in 18.18.1 and water-cement ratio in
18.18.3.3 are retained in the Code.
18.18.2 — Materials for grout shall conform to R18.18.2 — The limitations on admixtures in 3.6 apply to
18.18.2.1 through 18.18.2.4. grout. Substances known to be harmful to tendons, grout, or
concrete are chlorides, fluorides, sulfites, and nitrates.
18.18.2.1 — Portland cement shall conform to 3.2. Aluminum powder or other expansive admixtures, when
approved, should produce an unconfined expansion of 5 to
18.18.2.2 — Water shall conform to 3.4. 10 percent. Neat cement grout is used in almost all building
construction. Use of finely graded sand in the grout should
18.18.2.3 — Sand, if used, shall conform to ASTM only be considered with large ducts having large void areas.
C144 except that gradation shall be permitted to be
modified as necessary to obtain satisfactory workability.
18.18.2.4 — Admixtures conforming to 3.6 and
known to have no injurious effects on grout, steel, or
concrete shall be permitted. Calcium chloride shall not
be used.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 311
CODE COMMENTARY
18.18.3 — Selection of grout proportions R18.18.3 — Selection of grout proportions
18.18.3.1 — Proportions of materials for grout shall Grout proportioned in accordance with these provisions will
be based on either (a) or (b): generally lead to 7-day compressive strength on standard
2 in. cubes in excess of 2500 psi and 28-day strengths of
(a) Results of tests on fresh and hardened grout about 4000 psi. The handling and placing properties of
prior to beginning grouting operations; or grout are usually given more consideration than strength
when designing grout mixtures.
(b) Prior documented experience with similar
materials and equipment and under comparable field
conditions.
18.18.3.2 — Cement used in the Work shall corre-
spond to that on which selection of grout proportions
was based.
18.18.3.3 — Water content shall be minimum
necessary for proper pumping of grout; however,
water-cement ratio shall not exceed 0.45 by weight.
18.18.3.4 — Water shall not be added to increase
grout flowability that has been decreased by delayed
use of the grout.
18.18.4 — Mixing and pumping grout R18.18.4 — Mixing and pumping grout
18.18.4.1 — Grout shall be mixed in equipment In an ambient temperature of 35°F, grout with an initial
capable of continuous mechanical mixing and agitation minimum temperature of 60°F may require as much as 5 days
that will produce uniform distribution of materials, to reach 800 psi. A minimum grout temperature of 60°F is
passed through screens, and pumped in a manner suggested because it is consistent with the recommended
that will completely fill the ducts. minimum temperature for concrete placed at an ambient
temperature of 35°F. Quickset grouts, when approved, may
18.18.4.2 — Temperature of members at time of require shorter periods of protection, and the recommenda-
grouting shall be above 35°F and shall be maintained tions of the suppliers should be followed. Test cubes should
above 35°F until field-cured 2 in. cubes of grout reach be cured under temperature and moisture conditions as close
a minimum compressive strength of 800 psi. as possible to those of the grout in the member. Grout temper-
atures in excess of 90°F will lead to difficulties in pumping.
18.18.4.3 — Grout temperatures shall not be above
90°F during mixing and pumping.
18.19 — Protection for prestressing steel
Burning or welding operations in the vicinity of
prestressing steel shall be performed so that
prestressing steel is not subject to excessive
temperatures, welding sparks, or ground currents.
18.20 — Application and measurement of R18.20 — Application and measurement of
prestressing force prestressing force
18.20.1 — Prestressing force shall be determined by R18.20.1 — Elongation measurements for prestressed
both of (a) and (b): elements should be in accordance with the procedures
outlined in the Manual for Quality Control for Plants and
(a) Measurement of steel elongation. Required elon- Production Structural Precast Concrete Products, published
gation shall be determined from average load-elon- by the Precast/Prestressed Concrete Institute.18.34
gation curves for the prestressing steel used;
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
312 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
(b) Observation of jacking force on a calibrated gage Section 18.18.1 of the 1989 Code was revised to permit
or load cell or by use of a calibrated dynamometer. 7 percent tolerance in prestressing steel force determined by
gauge pressure and elongation measurements for post-
Cause of any difference in force determination tensioned construction. Elongation measurements for post-
between (a) and (b) that exceeds 5 percent for preten- tensioned construction are affected by several factors that
sioned elements or 7 percent for post-tensioned are less significant, or that do not exist, for pretensioned
construction shall be ascertained and corrected. elements. The friction along prestressing steel in post-
tensioning applications may be affected to varying degrees
by placing tolerances and small irregularities in tendon
profile due to concrete placement. The friction coefficients
between the prestressing steel and the duct are also subject
to variation. The 5 percent tolerance that has appeared since
the 1963 Code was proposed by Committee 423 in 1958,18.6
and primarily reflected experience with production of
pretensioned concrete elements. Because the tendons for
pretensioned elements are usually stressed in the air with
minimal friction effects, the 5 percent tolerance for such
elements was retained.
18.20.2 — Where the transfer of force from the bulk-
heads of pretensioning bed to the concrete is accom-
plished by flame cutting prestressing steel, cutting
points and cutting sequence shall be predetermined to
avoid undesired temporary stresses.
18.20.3 — Long lengths of exposed pretensioned
strand shall be cut near the member to minimize shock
to concrete.
18.20.4 — Total loss of prestress due to unreplaced R18.20.4 — This provision applies to all prestressed
broken prestressing steel shall not exceed 2 percent of concrete members. For cast-in-place post-tensioned slab
total prestress. systems, a member should be that portion considered as an
element in the design, such as the joist and effective slab
width in one-way joist systems, or the column strip or
middle strip in two-way flat plate systems.
18.21 — Post-tensioning anchorages and R18.21 — Post-tensioning anchorages and
couplers couplers
18.21.1 — Anchorages and couplers for bonded and R18.21.1 — In the 1986 interim Code, the separate provisions
unbonded tendons shall develop at least 95 percent of for strength of unbonded and bonded tendon anchorages and
the f when tested in an unbonded condition, without couplers presented in 18.19.1 and 18.19.2 of the 1983 Code
pu
exceeding anticipated set. For bonded tendons, were combined into a single revised 18.21 covering anchorages
anchorages and couplers shall be located so that 100 and couplers for both unbonded and bonded tendons. Since
percent of f shall be developed at critical sections the 1989 Code, the required strength of the tendon-
pu
after the prestressing steel is bonded in the member. anchorage or tendon-coupler assemblies for both unbonded
and bonded tendons, when tested in an unbonded state, is
based on 95 percent of the specified breaking strength of the
prestressing steel in the test. The prestressing steel material
should comply with the minimum provisions of the appli-
cable ASTM specifications as outlined in 3.5.5. The speci-
fied strength of anchorages and couplers exceeds the
maximum design strength of the prestressing steel by a
substantial margin and, at the same time, recognizes the
stress-riser effects associated with most available post-
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 313
CODE COMMENTARY
tensioning anchorages and couplers. Anchorage and coupler
strength should be attained with a minimum amount of
permanent deformation and successive set, recognizing that
some deformation and set will occur when testing to failure.
Tendon assemblies should conform to the 2 percent elongation
requirements in ACI 30118.35 and industry recommenda-
tions.18.30 Anchorages and couplers for bonded tendons that
develop less than 100 percent of the specified breaking
strength of the prestressing steel should be used only where
the bond transfer length between the anchorage or coupler
and critical sections equals or exceeds that required to
develop the prestressing steel strength. This bond length may
be calculated by the results of tests of bond characteristics of
untensioned prestressing strand,18.36 or by bond tests on
other prestressing steel materials, as appropriate.
18.21.2 — Couplers shall be placed in areas approved
by the licensed design professional and enclosed in
housing long enough to permit necessary movements.
18.21.3 — In unbonded construction subject to repetitive R18.21.3 — For discussion on fatigue loading, see Reference
loads, attention shall be given to the possibility of 18.37.
fatigue in anchorages and couplers.
For detailed recommendations on tests for static and cyclic
loading conditions for tendons and anchorage fittings of
unbonded tendons, see Section 4.1.3 of Reference 18.12,
and Section 15.2.2 of Reference 18.35.
18.21.4 — Anchorages, couplers, and end fittings shall R18.21.4 — For recommendations regarding protection see
be permanently protected against corrosion. Sections 4.2 and 4.3 of Reference 18.12, and Sections 3.4,
3.6, 5, 6, and 8.3 of Reference 18.30.
18.22 — External post-tensioning R18.22 — External post-tensioning
18.22.1 — Post-tensioning tendons shall be permitted External attachment of tendons is a versatile method of
to be external to any concrete section of a member. providing additional strength, or improving serviceability,
The strength and serviceability design methods of this or both, in existing structures. It is well suited to repair or
Code shall be used in evaluating the effects of external upgrade existing structures and permits a wide variety of
tendon forces on the concrete structure. tendon arrangements.
18.22.2 — External tendons shall be considered as Additional information on external post-tensioning is given
unbonded tendons when computing flexural strength in Reference 18.38.
unless provisions are made to effectively bond the
external tendons to the concrete section along its
entire length.
18.22.3 — External tendons shall be attached to the R18.22.3 — External tendons are often attached to the
concrete member in a manner that maintains the concrete member at various locations between anchorages
desired eccentricity between the tendons and the (such as midspan, quarter points, or third points) for desired
concrete centroid throughout the full range of antici- load balancing effects, for tendon alignment, or to address
pated member deflection. tendon vibration concerns. Consideration should be given to
the effects caused by the tendon profile shifting in relationship
to the concrete centroid as the member deforms under
effects of post-tensioning and applied load.
