18.22.4 — External tendons and tendon anchorage R18.22.4 — Permanent corrosion protection can be
regions shall be protected against corrosion, and the achieved by a variety of methods. The corrosion protection
details of the protection method shall be indicated in provided should be suitable to the environment in which the
the contract documents. tendons are located. Some conditions will require that the
prestressing steel be protected by concrete cover or by
cement grout in polyethylene or metal tubing; other conditions
will permit the protection provided by coatings such as paint
or grease. Corrosion protection methods should meet the
fire protection requirements of the general building code,
unless the installation of external post-tensioning is to only
improve serviceability.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 315
CHAPTER 19 — SHELLS AND FOLDED PLATE MEMBERS
CODE COMMENTARY
19.1 — Scope and definitions R19.1 — Scope and definitions
The Code and Commentary provide information on the
design, analysis, and construction of concrete thin shells
and folded plates. The process began in 1964 with the
publication of a practice and commentary by ACI
Committee 334,19.1 and continued with the inclusion of
Chapter 19 in the 1971 Code. The 1982 revision of ACI
334.1R reflected additional experience in design, analysis,
and construction and was influenced by the publication of
the “Recommendations for Reinforced Concrete Shells
and Folded Plates” of the International Association for
Shell and Spatial Structures (IASS) in 1979.19.2
Since Chapter 19 applies to concrete thin shells and folded
plates of all shapes, extensive discussion of their design,
analysis, and construction in the Commentary is not
possible. Additional information can be obtained from the
references. Performance of shells and folded plates requires
attention to detail.19.3
19.1.1 — Provisions of Chapter 19 shall apply to thin
shell and folded plate concrete structures, including
ribs and edge members.
19.1.2 — All provisions of this Code not specifically
excluded, and not in conflict with provisions of
Chapter 19, shall apply to thin-shell structures.
19.1.3 — Thin shells — Three-dimensional spatial R19.1.3 — Common types of thin shells are domes
structures made up of one or more curved slabs or (surfaces of revolution),19.4,19.5 cylindrical shells,19.5 barrel
folded plates whose thicknesses are small compared vaults,19.6 conoids,19.6 elliptical paraboloids,19.6 hyperbolic
to their other dimensions. Thin shells are characterized paraboloids,19.7 and groined vaults.19.7
by their three-dimensional load-carrying behavior,
which is determined by the geometry of their forms, by
the manner in which they are supported, and by the
nature of the applied load.
19.1.4 — Folded plates — A class of shell structure R19.1.4 — Folded plates may be prismatic,19.4,19.5 nonpris-
formed by joining flat, thin slabs along their edges to matic,19.5 or faceted. The first two types consist generally of
create a three-dimensional spatial structure. planar thin slabs joined along their longitudinal edges to
form a beam-like structure spanning between supports.
Faceted folded plates are made up of triangular or polygonal
planar thin slabs joined along their edges to form three-
dimensional spatial structures.
19.1.5 — Ribbed shells — Spatial structures with R19.1.5 — Ribbed shells19.6,19.7 generally have been used
material placed primarily along certain preferred rib for larger spans where the increased thickness of the curved
lines, with the area between the ribs filled with thin slab alone becomes excessive or uneconomical. Ribbed
slabs or left open. shells are also used because of the construction techniques
employed and to enhance the aesthetic impact of the
completed structure.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
316 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
19.1.6 — Auxiliary members — Ribs or edge beams R19.1.6 — Most thin shell structures require ribs or edge
that serve to strengthen, stiffen, or support the shell; beams at their boundaries to carry the shell boundary forces,
usually, auxiliary members act jointly with the shell. to assist in transmitting them to the supporting structure,
and to accommodate the increased amount of reinforcement
in these areas.
19.1.7 — Elastic analysis — An analysis of defor- R19.1.7 — Elastic analysis of thin shells and folded plates
mations and internal forces based on equilibrium, can be performed using any method of structural analysis
compatibility of strains, and assumed elastic behavior, based on assumptions that provide suitable approximations
and representing to a suitable approximation the to the three-dimensional behavior of the structure. The
three-dimensional action of the shell together with its method should determine the internal forces and displace-
auxiliary members. ments needed in the design of the shell proper, the rib or
edge members, and the supporting structure. Equilibrium of
internal forces and external loads and compatibility of
deformations should be satisfied.
Methods of elastic analysis based on classical shell theory,
simplified mathematical or analytical models, or numerical
solutions using finite element,19.8 finite differences,19.6 or
numerical integration techniques,19.6,19.9 are described in
the cited references.
The choice of the method of analysis and the degree of
accuracy required depends on certain critical factors. These
include: the size of the structure, the geometry of the thin
shell or folded plate, the manner in which the structure is
supported, the nature of the applied load, and the extent of
personal or documented experience regarding the reliability
of the given method of analysis in predicting the behavior of
the specific type of shell19.6 or folded plate.19.5
19.1.8 — Inelastic analysis — An analysis of deforma- R19.1.8 — Inelastic analysis of thin shells and folded plates
tions and internal forces based on equilibrium, can be performed using a refined method of analysis based
nonlinear stress-strain relations for concrete and on the specific nonlinear material properties, nonlinear
reinforcement, consideration of cracking and time- behavior due to the cracking of concrete, and time-depen-
dependent effects, and compatibility of strains. The dent effects such as creep, shrinkage, temperature, and load
analysis shall represent to a suitable approximation history. These effects are incorporated in order to trace the
three-dimensional action of the shell together with its response and crack propagation of a reinforced concrete
auxiliary members. shell through the elastic, inelastic, and ultimate ranges. Such
analyses usually require incremental loading and iterative
procedures to converge on solutions that satisfy both
equilibrium and strain compatibility. 19.10,19.11
19.1.9 — Experimental analysis — An analysis
procedure based on the measurement of deformations
or strains, or both, of the structure or its model; experi-
mental analysis is based on either elastic or inelastic
behavior.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 317
CODE COMMENTARY
19.2 — Analysis and design R19.2 — Analysis and design
19.2.1 — Elastic behavior shall be an accepted basis R19.2.1 — For types of shell structures where experience,
for determining internal forces and displacements of tests, and analyses have shown that the structure can sustain
thin shells. This behavior shall be permitted to be reasonable overloads without undergoing brittle failure,
established by computations based on an analysis of elastic analysis is an acceptable procedure. In such cases, it
the uncracked concrete structure in which the material may be assumed that reinforced concrete is ideally elastic,
is assumed linearly elastic, homogeneous, and homogeneous, and isotropic, having identical properties in
isotropic. Poisson’s ratio of concrete shall be permitted all directions. An analysis should be performed for the shell
to be taken equal to zero. considering service load conditions. The analysis of shells
of unusual size, shape, or complexity should consider
behavior through the elastic, cracking, and inelastic stages.
19.2.2 — Inelastic analyses shall be permitted to be R19.2.2 — Several inelastic analysis procedures contain
used where it can be shown that such methods possible solution methods.19.10,19.11
provide a safe basis for design.
19.2.3 — Equilibrium checks of internal resistances
and external loads shall be made to ensure consis-
tency of results.
19.2.4 — Experimental or numerical analysis procedures R19.2.4 — Experimental analysis of elastic models19.12 has
shall be permitted where it can be shown that such been used as a substitute for an analytical solution of a
procedures provide a safe basis for design. complex shell structure. Experimental analysis of reinforced
microconcrete models through the elastic, cracking,
inelastic, and ultimate stages should be considered for
important shells of unusual size, shape, or complexity.
For model analysis, only those portions of the structure that
significantly affect the items under study need be simulated.
Every attempt should be made to ensure that the experiments
reveal the quantitative behavior of the prototype structure.
Wind tunnel tests of a scaled-down model do not necessarily
provide usable results and should be conducted by a
recognized expert in wind tunnel testing of structural models.
19.2.5 — Approximate methods of analysis shall be R19.2.5 — Solutions that include both membrane and bending
permitted where it can be shown that such methods effects and satisfy conditions of compatibility and equilibrium
provide a safe basis for design. are encouraged. Approximate solutions that satisfy statics but
not the compatibility of strains may be used only when extensive
experience has proved that safe designs have resulted from their
use. Such methods include beam-type analysis for barrel shells
and folded plates having large ratios of span to either width or
radius of curvature, simple membrane analysis for shells of
revolution, and others in which the equations of equilibrium
are satisfied, while the strain compatibility equations are not.
19.2.6 — In prestressed shells, the analysis shall also R19.2.6 — If the shell is prestressed, the analysis should
consider behavior under loads induced during include its strength at factored loads as well as its adequacy
prestressing, at cracking load, and at factored load. under service loads, under the load that causes cracking, and
Where tendons are draped within a shell, design shall under loads induced during prestressing. Axial forces due to
take into account force components on the shell draped tendons may not lie in one plane, and due consider-
resulting from the tendon profile not lying in one plane. ation should be given to the resulting force components. The
effects of post-tensioning of shell-supporting members
should be taken into account.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
318 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
19.2.7 — The thickness of a shell and its reinforce- R19.2.7 — The thin shell’s thickness and reinforcement are
ment shall be proportioned for the required strength required to be proportioned to satisfy the strength provisions
and serviceability, using either the strength design of this Code, and to resist internal forces obtained from an
method of 8.1.1 or the design method of 8.1.2. analysis, an experimental model study, or a combination
thereof. Reinforcement sufficient to minimize cracking
under service load conditions should be provided. The
thickness of the shell is often dictated by the required
reinforcement and the construction constraints, by 19.2.8,
or by the Code minimum thickness requirements.
19.2.8 — Shell instability shall be investigated and R19.2.8 — Thin shells, like other structures that experience in-
shown by design to be precluded. plane membrane compressive forces, are subject to buckling
when the applied load reaches a critical value. Because of the
surface-like geometry of shells, the problem of calculating
buckling load is complex. If one of the principal membrane
forces is tensile, the shell is less likely to buckle than if both
principal membrane forces are compressive. The kinds of
membrane forces that develop in a shell depend on its initial
shape and the manner in which the shell is supported and
loaded. In some types of shells, post-buckling behavior should
be considered in determining safety against instability.19.2
Investigation of thin shells for stability should consider the
effect of: (1) anticipated deviation of the geometry of the
shell surface as-built from the idealized geometry; (2) large
deflections; (3) creep and shrinkage of concrete; (4)
inelastic properties of materials; (5) cracking of concrete;
(6) location, amount, and orientation of reinforcement; and
(7) possible deformation of supporting elements.
Measures successfully used to improve resistance to buckling
include the provision of two mats of reinforcement—one
near each outer surface of the shell, a local increase of shell
curvatures, the use of ribbed shells, and the use of concrete
with high tensile strength and low creep.
A procedure for determining critical buckling loads of shells
is given in the IASS recommendations.19.2 Some recom-
mendations for buckling design of domes used in industrial
applications are given in References 19.13 and 19.14.
19.2.9 — Auxiliary members shall be designed
according to the applicable provisions of the Code. It
shall be permitted to assume that a portion of the shell
equal to the flange width, as specified in 8.12, acts with
the auxiliary member. In such portions of the shell, the
reinforcement perpendicular to the auxiliary member
shall be at least equal to that required for the flange of
a T-beam by 8.12.5.
19.2.10 — Strength design of shell slabs for R19.2.10 — The stresses and strains in the shell slab used
membrane and bending forces shall be based on the for design are those determined by analysis (elastic or
distribution of stresses and strains as determined from inelastic) multiplied by appropriate load factors. Because of
either an elastic or an inelastic analysis. detrimental effects of membrane cracking, the computed
tensile strain in the reinforcement under factored loads
should be limited.

19.4 — Shell reinforcement R19.4 — Shell reinforcement
19.4.1 — Shell reinforcement shall be provided to R19.4.1 — At any point in a shell, two different kinds of
resist tensile stresses from internal membrane forces, internal forces may occur simultaneously: those associated
to resist tension from bending and twisting moments, with membrane action, and those associated with bending of
to limit shrinkage and temperature crack width and the shell. The membrane forces are assumed to act in the
spacing, and as reinforcement at shell boundaries, tangential plane midway between the surfaces of the shell,
load attachments, and shell openings. and are the two axial forces and the membrane shears. Flexural
effects include bending moments, twisting moments, and
the associated transverse shears. Limiting membrane crack
width and spacing due to shrinkage, temperature, and
service load conditions is a major design consideration.
19.4.2 — Tensile reinforcement shall be provided in R19.4.2 — The requirement of ensuring strength in all
two or more directions and shall be proportioned such directions is based on safety considerations. Any method
that its resistance in any direction equals or exceeds that ensures sufficient strength consistent with equilibrium
the component of internal forces in that direction. is acceptable. The direction of the principal membrane
tensile force at any point may vary depending on the direction,
Alternatively, reinforcement for the membrane forces in magnitudes, and combinations of the various applied loads.
the slab shall be calculated as the reinforcement
The magnitude of the internal membrane forces, acting at
required to resist axial tensile forces plus the tensile
any point due to a specific load, is generally calculated on
force due to shear-friction required to transfer shear
the basis of an elastic theory in which the shell is assumed
across any cross section of the membrane. The
assumed coefficient of friction, μ, shall not exceed that as uncracked. The computation of the required amount of
reinforcement to resist the internal membrane forces has
specified in 11.6.4.3.
been traditionally based on the assumption that concrete
does not resist tension. The associated deflections, and the
possibility of cracking, should be investigated in the
serviceability phase of the design. Achieving this may
require a working stress design for steel selection.
Where reinforcement is not placed in the direction of the
principal tensile forces and where cracks at the service load
level are objectionable, the computation of reinforcement may
have to be based on a more refined approach19.15,19.17,19.18
that considers the existence of cracks. In the cracked state,
the concrete is assumed to be unable to resist either tension
or shear. Thus, equilibrium is attained by equating tensile-
resisting forces in reinforcement and compressive-resisting
forces in concrete.
The alternative method to calculate orthogonal reinforcement
is the shear-friction method. It is based on the assumption
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
320 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
that shear integrity of a shell should be maintained at
factored loads. It is not necessary to calculate principal
stresses if the alternative approach is used.

moments about axes in the plane of the shell slab

19.4.6 — In regions of high tension, membrane R19.4.6 — Generally, for all shells, and particularly in
reinforcement shall, if practical, be placed in the regions of substantial tension, the orientation of reinforcement
general directions of the principal tensile membrane should approximate the directions of the principal tensile
forces. Where this is not practical, it shall be permitted membrane forces. However, in some structures it is not
to place membrane reinforcement in two or more possible to detail the reinforcement to follow the stress

19.4.7 — If the direction of reinforcement varies more R19.4.7 — When the directions of reinforcement deviate
than 10 degrees from the direction of principal tensile significantly (more than 10 degrees) from the directions of
membrane force, the amount of reinforcement shall be the principal membrane forces, higher strains in the shell
reviewed in relation to cracking at service loads. occur to develop the reinforcement. This might lead to the
development of unacceptable wide cracks. The crack width
should be estimated and limited if necessary.
Permissible crack widths for service loads under different
environmental conditions are given in a report of ACI
Committee 224.19.19 Crack width can be limited by an
increase in the amount of reinforcement used, by reducing
the stress at the service load level, by providing reinforcement
in three or more directions in the plane of the shell, or by
using closer spacing of smaller-diameter bars.

STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 323
CHAPTER 20 — STRENGTH EVALUATION OF EXISTING
STRUCTURES
CODE COMMENTARY
20.1 — Strength evaluation — General R20.1 — Strength evaluation — General
20.1.1 — If there is doubt that a part or all of a structure Chapter 20 does not cover load testing for the approval of
meets the safety requirements of this Code, a strength new design or construction methods. (See 16.10 for recom-
evaluation shall be carried out as required by the mendations on strength evaluation of precast concrete
licensed design professional or building official. members.) Provisions of Chapter 20 may be used to evaluate
whether a structure or a portion of a structure satisfies the
safety requirements of this Code. A strength evaluation may
be required if the materials are considered to be deficient in
quality, if there is evidence indicating faulty construction, if
a structure has deteriorated, if a building will be used for a
new function, or if, for any reason, a structure or a portion
of it does not appear to satisfy the requirements of the Code.
In such cases, Chapter 20 provides guidance for investigating
the safety of the structure.
If the safety concerns are related to an assembly of elements
or an entire structure, it is not feasible to load test every
element and section to the maximum. In such cases, it is
appropriate that an investigation plan be developed to
address the specific safety concerns. If a load test is
described as part of the strength evaluation process, it is
desirable for all parties involved to come to an agreement
about the region to be loaded, the magnitude of the load, the
load test procedure, and acceptance criteria before any load
tests are conducted.
20.1.2 — If the effect of the strength deficiency is well R20.1.2 — Strength considerations related to axial load,
understood and if it is feasible to measure the flexure, and combined axial load and flexure are well under-
dimensions and material properties required for analysis, stood. There are reliable theories relating strength and short-
analytical evaluations of strength based on those term displacement to load in terms of dimensional and
measurements shall suffice. Required data shall be material data for the structure.
determined in accordance with 20.2.
To determine the strength of the structure by analysis, calcu-
lations should be based on data gathered on the actual
dimensions of the structure, properties of the materials in
place, and all pertinent details. Requirements for data
collection are in 20.2.
20.1.3 — If the effect of the strength deficiency is not R20.1.3 — If the shear or bond strength of an element is
well understood or if it is not feasible to establish the critical in relation to the doubt expressed about safety, a test
required dimensions and material properties by may be the most efficient solution to eliminate or confirm
measurement, a load test shall be required if the the doubt. A test may also be appropriate if it is not feasible
structure is to remain in service. to determine the material and dimensional properties
required for analysis, even if the cause of the concern relates
to flexure or axial load.
Wherever possible and appropriate, support the results of
the load test by analysis.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
324 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
20.1.4 — If the doubt about safety of a part or all of a R20.1.4 — For a deteriorating structure, the acceptance
structure involves deterioration, and if the observed provided by the load test may not be assumed to be without
response during the load test satisfies the acceptance limits in terms of time. In such cases, a periodic inspection
criteria, the structure or part of the structure shall be program is useful. A program that involves physical tests
permitted to remain in service for a specified time and periodic inspection can justify a longer period in
period. If deemed necessary by the licensed design service. Another option for maintaining the structure in
professional, periodic reevaluations shall be conducted. service, while the periodic inspection program continues, is
to limit the live load to a level determined to be appropriate.
The length of the specified time period should be based on
consideration of: (a) the nature of the problem; (b) environ-
mental and load effects; (c) service history of the structure;
and (d) scope of the periodic inspection program. At the end
of a specified time period, further strength evaluation is
required if the structure is to remain in service.
With the agreement of all concerned parties, procedures
may be devised for periodic testing that do not necessarily
conform to the loading and acceptance criteria specified in
Chapter 20.

evaluation (see 20.1.2).

20.3 — Load test procedure R20.3 — Load test procedure
20.3.1 — Load arrangement R20.3.1—Load arrangement
The number and arrangement of spans or panels It is important to apply the load at locations so that its
loaded shall be selected to maximize the deflection and effects on the suspected defect are a maximum and the prob-
stresses in the critical regions of the structural elements ability of unloaded members sharing the applied load is a
of which strength is in doubt. More than one test load minimum. In cases where it is shown by analysis that
arrangement shall be used if a single arrangement will adjoining unloaded elements will help carry some of the
not simultaneously result in maximum values of the load, the load should be placed to develop effects consistent
effects (such as deflection, rotation, or stress) necessary with the intent of the load factor.
to demonstrate the adequacy of the structure.
20.3.2 — Load intensity R20.3.2 — Load intensity

shall not be less than the larger of (a), (b), and (c): The live load L may be reduced as permitted by the general

326 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
20.3.3 — A load test shall not be made until that
portion of the structure to be subjected to load is at
least 56 days old. If the owner of the structure, the
contractor, and all involved parties agree, it shall be
permitted to make the test at an earlier age.
20.4 — Loading criteria R20.4 — Loading criteria
20.4.1 — The initial value for all applicable response
measurements (such as deflection, rotation, strain,
slip, crack widths) shall be obtained not more than 1 hour
before application of the first load increment. Measure-
ments shall be made at locations where maximum
response is expected. Additional measurements shall
be made if required.
20.4.2 — Test load shall be applied in not less than R20.4.2 — Inspecting the structure after each load increment
four approximately equal increments. is advisable.
20.4.3 — Uniform test load shall be applied in a manner R20.4.3 — Arching refers to the tendency for the load to be
to ensure uniform distribution of the load transmitted to transmitted nonuniformly to the flexural element being
the structure or portion of the structure being tested. tested. For example, if a slab is loaded by a uniform
Arching of the applied load shall be avoided. arrangement of bricks with the bricks in contact, arching
would results in reduction of the load on the slab near the
midspan of the slab.
20.4.4 — A set of response measurements shall be
made after each load increment is applied and after
the total load has been applied on the structure for at
least 24 hours.
20.4.5 — Total test load shall be removed immediately
after all response measurements defined in 20.4.4 are
made.
20.4.6 — A set of final response measurements shall
be made 24 hours after the test load is removed.
20.5 — Acceptance criteria R20.5 — Acceptance criteria
20.5.1 — The portion of the structure tested shall R20.5.1 — A general acceptance criterion for the behavior of
show no evidence of failure. Spalling and crushing of a structure under the test load is that it does not show
compressed concrete shall be considered an indication evidence of failure. Evidence of failure includes cracking,
of failure. spalling, or deflection of such magnitude and extent that the
observed result is obviously excessive and incompatible with
the safety requirements of the structure. No simple rules have
been developed for application to all types of structures and
conditions. If sufficient damage has occurred so that the
structure is considered to have failed that test, retesting is not
permitted because it is considered that damaged members
should not be put into service even at a lower load rating.
Local spalling or flaking of the compressed concrete in flexural
elements related to casting imperfections need not indicate
overall structural distress. Crack widths are good indicators
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 327
CODE COMMENTARY
of the state of the structure and should be observed to help
determine whether the structure is satisfactory. However,
exact prediction or measurement of crack widths in reinforced
concrete elements is not likely to be achieved under field
conditions. Establish criteria before the test, relative to the
types of cracks anticipated; where the cracks will be
measured; how they will be measured; and approximate
limits or criteria to evaluate new cracks or limits for the
changes in crack width.
20.5.2 — Measured deflections shall satisfy either R20.5.2 — The deflection limits and the retest option

20.5.3 — Structural members tested shall not have R20.5.3 — Forces are transmitted across a shear crack plane
cracks indicating the imminence of shear failure. by a combination of aggregate interlock at the interface of
the crack that is enhanced by clamping action of transverse
stirrup reinforcing and by dowel action of stirrups crossing
the crack. As crack lengths increase to approach a horizontal
projected length equal to the depth of the member and
concurrently widen to the extent that aggregate interlock
cannot occur, and as transverse stirrups if present begin to
yield or display loss of anchorage so as to threaten their
integrity, the member is assumed to be approaching imminent
shear failure.
20.5.4 — In regions of structural members without R20.5.4 — The intent of 20.5.4 is to make the professionals
transverse reinforcement, appearance of structural in charge of the test pay attention to the structural implication
cracks inclined to the longitudinal axis and having a of observed inclined cracks that may lead to brittle collapse
horizontal projection longer than the depth of the in members without transverse reinforcement.
member at midpoint of the crack shall be evaluated.

328 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
20.5.5 — In regions of anchorage and lap splices, the R20.5.5 — Cracking along the axis of the reinforcement in
appearance along the line of reinforcement of a series anchorage zones may be related to high stresses associated
of short inclined cracks or horizontal cracks shall be with the transfer of forces between the reinforcement and
evaluated. the concrete. These cracks may be indicators of pending
brittle failure of the element if they are associated with the
main reinforcement. It is important that their causes and
consequences be evaluated.
20.6 — Provision for lower load rating R20.6 — Provision for lower load rating
If the structure under investigation does not satisfy Except for load tested members that have failed under a test
conditions or criteria of 20.1.2, 20.5.2, or 20.5.3, the (see 20.5), the building official may permit the use of a
structure shall be permitted for use at a lower load structure or member at a lower load rating that is judged to
rating based on the results of the load test or analysis, be safe and appropriate on the basis of the test results.
if approved by the building official.
20.7 — Safety
20.7.1 — Load tests shall be conducted in such a
manner as to provide for safety of life and structure
during the test.
20.7.2 — Safety measures shall not interfere with load
test procedures or affect results.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org

Structures assigned to SDC C may be subjected to moderately
21.1.1.8 — A reinforced concrete structural system
strong ground shaking. The designated seismic-force-
not satisfying the requirements of this chapter shall be
resisting system typically comprises some combination of
permitted if it is demonstrated by experimental
ordinary cast-in-place structural walls, intermediate precast
evidence and analysis that the proposed system will
structural walls, and intermediate moment frames. The

seismic-force-resisting systems in SDC C. Section 21.1.1.7

Structures assigned to SDC D, E, or F may be subjected to
strong ground shaking. It is the intent of Committee 318 that
the seismic-force-resisting system of structural concrete
buildings assigned to SDC D, E, or F be provided by special
moment frames, special structural walls, or a combination
of the two. In addition to 21.1.2 through 21.1.8, these
structures also are required to satisfy requirements for
continuous inspection (1.3.5), diaphragms and trusses
(21.11), foundations (21.12), and gravity-load-resisting
elements that are not designated as part of the seismic-
force-resisting system (21.13). These provisions have been
developed to provide the structure with adequate toughness
for the high demands expected for these SDCs.
The legally adopted general building code of which this
Code forms a part may also permit the use of intermediate
moment frames as part of dual systems for some buildings
assigned to SDC D, E, or F. It is not the intention of
Committee 318 to recommend the use of intermediate
moment frames as part of moment-resisting frame or dual
systems in SDC D, E, or F. The legally adopted general
building code may also permit substantiated alternative or
nonprescriptive designs or, with various supplementary provi-
sions, the use of ordinary or intermediate systems for
nonbuilding structures in the higher SDCs. These are not the
typical applications around which this chapter is written, but
wherever the term “ordinary” or “intermediate” moment frame
is used in reference to reinforced concrete, 21.2 or 21.3 apply.
Table R21.1.1 summarizes the applicability of the provisions
of Chapter 21 as they are typically applied where using
minimum requirements in the various SDCs. Where special
systems are used for structures in SDC B or C, it is not
required to satisfy the requirements of 21.13, although it
should be verified that members not designated as part of
the seismic-force-resisting system will be stable under
design displacements.
The proportioning and detailing requirements in Chapter 21
are based predominantly on field and laboratory experience
with monolithic reinforced concrete building structures and

precast concrete building structures designed and detailed to

these requirements to other types of cast-in-place or precast
concrete structures should be based on evidence provided
by field experience, tests, or analysis. The acceptance
criteria for moment frames given in ACI 374.1 can be used
in conjunction with Chapter 21 to demonstrate that the
strength and toughness of a proposed frame system equals
or exceeds that provided by a comparable monolithic
concrete system. ACI ITG-5.1 provides similar information
for precast wall systems.
The toughness requirements in 21.1.1.8 refer to the concern
for the structural integrity of the entire seismic-force-
resisting system at lateral displacements anticipated for
ground motions corresponding to the design earthquake.
Depending on the energy-dissipation characteristics of the
structural system used, such displacements may be larger
than for a monolithic reinforced concrete structure.

members members

332 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
system is considered and accommodated in the struc- Because the design basis earthquake admits nonlinear
tural design. Consequences of failure of structural and response, it is necessary to investigate the stability of the
nonstructural members that are not a part of the seismic-force-resisting system as well as its interaction with
seismic-force-resisting system shall be considered. other structural and nonstructural members at displacements
larger than those indicated by linear analysis. To handle this
21.1.2.3 — Structural members extending below the without having to resort to nonlinear response analysis, one
base of structure that are required to transmit forces option is to multiply by a factor of at least two the displace-
resulting from earthquake effects to the foundation ments from linear analysis by using the factored lateral
shall comply with the requirements of Chapter 21 that forces, unless the legally adopted general building code
are consistent with the seismic-force-resisting system specifies the factors to be used as in the IBC or the UBC.
above the base of structure. For lateral displacement calculations, assuming all the
horizontal structural members to be fully cracked is likely to
lead to better estimates of the possible drift than using
uncracked stiffness for all members. The analysis
assumptions described in 8.8 also may be used to estimate
lateral deflections of reinforced concrete building systems.
The main objective of Chapter 21 is the safety of the structure.
The intent of 21.1.2.1 and 21.1.2.2 is to draw attention to
the influence of nonstructural members on structural
response and to hazards from falling objects.
Section 21.1.2.3 serves as an alert that the base of structure as
defined in analysis may not necessarily correspond to the
foundation or ground level. Details of columns and walls
extending below the base of structure to the foundation are
required to be consistent with those above the base of structure.
In selecting member sizes for earthquake-resistant struc-
tures, it is important to consider constructibility problems
related to congestion of reinforcement. The design should
be such that all reinforcement can be assembled and placed
in the proper location and that concrete can be cast and
consolidated properly. Use of upper limits of reinforcement
ratios permitted is likely to lead to insurmountable construction
problems, especially at frame joints.
21.1.3 — Strength reduction factors
Strength reduction factors shall be as given in 9.3.4.

21.1.7.2 — Welding of stirrups, ties, inserts, or other R21.1.7.2 — Welding of crossing reinforcing bars can
similar elements to longitudinal reinforcement that is lead to local embrittlement of the steel. If welding of
required by design shall not be permitted. crossing bars is used to facilitate fabrication or placement of
reinforcement, it should be done only on bars added for such
purposes. The prohibition of welding crossing reinforcing
bars does not apply to bars that are welded with welding
operations under continuous, competent control as in the
manufacture of welded wire reinforcement.
21.1.8 — Anchoring to concrete
Anchors resisting earthquake-induced forces in
structures assigned to SDC C, D, E, or F shall conform
to the requirements of D.3.3.

CODE COMMENTARY
21.2 — Ordinary moment frames R21.2 — Ordinary moment frames
21.2.1 — Scope These provisions were introduced in the 2008 Code and
apply only to ordinary moment frames assigned to SDC B.
Requirements of 21.2 apply to ordinary moment frames The provisions for beam reinforcement are intended to
forming part of the seismic-force-resisting system. improve continuity in the framing members as compared
with the provisions of Chapters 1 through 18 and thereby

21.3.4 — Beams
21.3.4.1 — The positive moment strength at the face
of the joint shall be not less than one-third the negative
moment strength provided at that face of the joint.
Neither the negative nor the positive moment strength
at any section along the length of the beam shall be
less than one-fifth the maximum moment strength
provided at the face of either joint.
21.3.4.2 — At both ends of the beam, hoops shall be
provided over lengths not less than 2h measured from
the face of the supporting member toward midspan.
The first hoop shall be located not more than 2 in. from
the face of the supporting member. Spacing of hoops
shall not exceed the smallest of (a), (b), (c), and (d):
(a) d/4;
(b) Eight times the diameter of the smallest longitu-
dinal bar enclosed;
(c) 24 times the diameter of the hoop bar;
(d) 12 in.
21.3.4.3 — Stirrups shall be spaced not more than
d/2 throughout the length of the beam.

supporting discontinuous stiff members.

1
21.5.2 — Longitudinal reinforcement R21.5.2 — Longitudinal reinforcement
Section 10.3.5 limits the net tensile strain, ε , thereby
t
indirectly limiting the tensile reinforcement ratio in a flexural
member to a fraction of the amount that would produce
balanced conditions. For a section subjected to bending only
and loaded monotonically to yielding, this approach is
feasible because the likelihood of compressive failure can
be estimated reliably with the behavioral model assumed for
determining the reinforcement ratio corresponding to
balanced failure. The same behavioral model (because of
incorrect assumptions such as linear strain distribution,
well-defined yield point for the steel, limiting compressive
strain in the concrete of 0.003, and compressive stresses in
the shell concrete) does not describe the conditions in a flexural
member subjected to reversals of displacements well into
the inelastic range. Thus, there is little rationale for
continuing to refer to balanced conditions in earthquake-
resistant design of reinforced concrete structures.
21.5.2.1 — At any section of a flexural member, R21.5.2.1 — The limiting reinforcement ratio of 0.025 is
except as provided in 10.5.3, for top as well as for based primarily on considerations of steel congestion and,
bottom reinforcement, the amount of reinforcement indirectly, on limiting shear stresses in beams of typical
shall not be less than that given by Eq. (10-3) but not proportions. The requirement of at least two bars, top and
less than 200b d/f , and the reinforcement ratio, ρ, bottom, refers again to construction rather than behavioral
w y
shall not exceed 0.025. At least two bars shall be requirements.
provided continuously at both top and bottom.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 341
CODE COMMENTARY

shall be not less than one-half the negative moment
strength provided at that face of the joint. Neither the
negative nor the positive moment strength at any
section along member length shall be less than one-
fourth the maximum moment strength provided at face
of either joint.

tendons are based on the results of analytical and experi-
(d) Anchorages of the post-tensioning tendons mental studies.21.16-21.18 Although satisfactory seismic
resisting earthquake-induced forces shall be performance can be obtained with greater amounts of
capable of allowing tendons to withstand 50 cycles prestressing steel, this restriction is needed to allow the use
of loading, bounded by 40 and 85 percent of the of the same response modification and deflection amplification
specified tensile strength of the prestressing steel. factors as those specified in model codes for special
moment frames without prestressing steel. Prestressed
special moment frames will generally contain continuous
prestressing steel that is anchored with adequate cover at or
beyond the exterior face of each beam-column connection
located at the ends of the moment frame.
Fatigue testing for 50 cycles of loading between 40 and
80 percent of the specified tensile strength of the prestressing
steel has been an industry practice of long standing.21.15,21.19
The 80 percent limit was increased to 85 percent to correspond
to the 1 percent limit on the strain in prestressing steel. Testing
over this range of stress is intended to conservatively
simulate the effect of a severe earthquake. Additional
details on testing procedures, but to different stress levels,
are provided in Reference 21.19.

not exceed 14 in. Skin reinforcement required by
10.6.7 need not be laterally supported.

21.5.4 — Shear strength requirements R21.5.4 — Shear strength requirements
21.5.4.1 — Design forces R21.5.4.1 — Design forces
The design shear force, V , shall be determined from In determining the equivalent lateral forces representing
e
consideration of the statical forces on the portion of earthquake effects for the type of frames considered, it is
the member between faces of the joints. It shall be assumed that frame members will dissipate energy in the
assumed that moments of opposite sign corresponding nonlinear range of response. Unless a frame member
to probable flexural moment strength, M , act at the possesses a strength that is on the order of 3 or 4 of the
pr
joint faces and that the member is loaded with the design forces, it should be assumed that it will yield in the
factored tributary gravity load along its span. event of a major earthquake. The design shear force should
be a good approximation of the maximum shear that may
develop in a member. Therefore, required shear strength for
frame members is related to flexural strengths of the
designed member rather than to factored shear forces indi-
cated by lateral load analysis. The conditions described by
21.5.4.1 are illustrated in Fig. R21.5.4.
Because the actual yield strength of the longitudinal
reinforcement may exceed the specified yield strength and
because strain hardening of the reinforcement is likely to
take place at a joint subjected to large rotations, required
shear strengths are determined using a stress of at least
1.25f in the longitudinal reinforcement.
y
21.5.4.2 — Transverse reinforcement R21.5.4.2 — Transverse reinforcement
Transverse reinforcement over the lengths identified in Experimental studies21.20,21.21 of reinforced concrete
21.5.3.1 shall be proportioned to resist shear members subjected to cyclic loading have demonstrated that
assuming V = 0 when both (a) and (b) occur: more shear reinforcement is required to ensure a flexural
c
failure if the member is subjected to alternating nonlinear
(a) The earthquake-induced shear force calculated displacements than if the member is loaded in only one
in accordance with 21.5.4.1 represents one-half or direction: the necessary increase of shear reinforcement
more of the maximum required shear strength within being higher in the case of no axial load. This observation is
those lengths; reflected in the Code (see 21.5.4.2) by eliminating the term
representing the contribution of concrete to shear strength.
(b) The factored axial compressive force, P ,
u The added conservatism on shear is deemed necessary in
including earthquake effects is less than A f′/20.
g c locations where potential flexural hinging may occur.
However, this stratagem, chosen for its relative simplicity,
should not be interpreted to mean that no concrete is
required to resist shear. On the contrary, it may be argued
that the concrete core resists all the shear with the shear
(transverse) reinforcement confining and strengthening the
concrete. The confined concrete core plays an important
role in the behavior of the beam and should not be reduced
to a minimum just because the design expression does not
explicitly recognize it.

21.6.2.3. in columns that are considered as part of the seismic-force-
resisting system. If columns are not stronger than beams
21.6.2.2 — The flexural strengths of the columns framing into a joint, there is likelihood of inelastic action. In

for reducing the design base shear. If inclusion of those
columns in the analytical model of the building results in an
increase in torsional effects, the increase should be considered
as required by the governing code. Furthermore, the column
must be provided with transverse reinforcement to increase
its toughness to resist shear and axial forces.
21.6.3 — Longitudinal reinforcement R21.6.3 — Longitudinal reinforcement
21.6.3.1 — Area of longitudinal reinforcement, A , The lower limit of the area of longitudinal reinforcement is
st
shall not be less than 0.01A or more than 0.06A . to control time-dependent deformations and to have the
g g
yield moment exceed the cracking moment. The upper limit
21.6.3.2 — In columns with circular hoops, the of the section reflects concern for steel congestion, load
minimum number of longitudinal bars shall be 6. transfer from floor elements to column (especially in low-rise
construction) and the development of high shear stresses.
21.6.3.3 — Mechanical splices shall conform to
21.1.6 and welded splices shall conform to 21.1.7. Lap Spalling of the shell concrete, which is likely to occur near
splices shall be permitted only within the center half of the ends of the column in frames of typical configuration,
the member length, shall be designed as tension lap makes lap splices in these locations vulnerable. If lap
splices, and shall be enclosed within transverse splices are to be used at all, they should be located near the
reinforcement conforming to 21.6.4.2 and 21.6.4.3. midheight where stress reversal is likely to be limited to a
smaller stress range than at locations near the joints.
Transverse reinforcement is required along the lap-splice
length because of the uncertainty in moment distributions
along the height and the need for confinement of lap splices
subjected to stress reversals.21.24
21.6.4 — Transverse reinforcement R21.6.4 — Transverse reinforcement
Requirements of this section are concerned with confining
the concrete and providing lateral support to the longitudinal
reinforcement.

21.7 — Joints of special moment frames R21.7 — Joints of special moment frames
21.7.1 — Scope
Requirements of 21.7 apply to beam-column joints of
special moment frames forming part of the seismic-
force-resisting system.
21.7.2 — General requirements R21.7.2 — General requirements
21.7.2.1 — Forces in longitudinal beam reinforcement Development of inelastic rotations at the faces of joints of
at the joint face shall be determined by assuming that reinforced concrete frames is associated with strains in the
the stress in the flexural tensile reinforcement is flexural reinforcement well in excess of the yield strain. Conse-

CODE COMMENTARY
21.7.2.3 — Where longitudinal beam reinforcement R21.7.2.3 — Research21.28-21.32 has shown that straight
extends through a beam-column joint, the column beam bars may slip within the beam-column joint during a
dimension parallel to the beam reinforcement shall not series of large moment reversals. The bond stresses on these
be less than 20 times the diameter of the largest longi- straight bars may be very large. To reduce slip substantially
tudinal beam bar for normalweight concrete. For light- during the formation of adjacent beam hinging, it would be
weight concrete, the dimension shall be not less than necessary to have a ratio of column dimension to bar diam-
26 times the bar diameter. eter of approximately 1/32, which would result in very large
joints. On reviewing the available tests, the limit of 1/20 of
the column depth in the direction of loading for the
maximum size of beam bars for normalweight concrete and
a limit of 1/26 for lightweight concrete were chosen. Due to
the lack of specific data for beam bars through lightweight
concrete joints, the limit was based on the amplification
factor of 1.3 in Chapter 12 starting with the 1989 Code. The
amplification factor was modified slightly in 2008 to 1/0.75
= 1.33, which did not affect this Code section. These limits
provide reasonable control on the amount of potential slip of
the beam bars in a beam-column joint, considering the
number of anticipated inelastic excursions of the building
frames during a major earthquake. A thorough treatment of
this topic is given in Reference 21.33.

coupling beams coupling beams

Requirements of 21.9 apply to special structural walls This section contains requirements for the dimensions and
and all components of special structural walls details of special structural walls and all components
including coupling beams and wall piers forming part including coupling beams and wall piers. Wall piers are
of the seismic-force-resisting system. Special structural defined in 2.2. Design provisions for vertical wall segments
walls constructed using precast concrete shall also depend on the aspect ratio of the wall segment in the plane
comply with 21.10. of the wall (h /l ), and the aspect ratio of the horizontal
w w
cross section (l /b ), and generally follow the descriptions
w w
in Table R21.9.1. The limiting aspect ratios for wall piers
are based on engineering judgment. It is intended that
flexural yielding of the vertical reinforcement in the pier
should limit shear demand on the pier.

21.9.3 — Design forces R21.9.3 — Design forces
V shall be obtained from the lateral load analysis in Design shears for structural walls are obtained from lateral
u
accordance with the factored load combinations. load analysis with the appropriate load factors. However, the
possibility of yielding in components of such structures
should be considered, as in the portion of a wall between
two window openings, in which case the actual shear may
be in excess of the shear indicated by lateral load analysis
based on factored design forces.

“Horizontal wall segments” in 21.9.4.5 refers to wall
sections between two vertically aligned openings (see
Fig. R21.9.4.5). It is, in effect, a vertical wall segment rotated
through 90 degrees. A horizontal wall segment is also
referred to as a coupling beam when the openings are
aligned vertically over the building height. When designing a
horizontal wall segment or coupling beam, ρ refers to vertical
t
reinforcement and ρ refers to horizontal reinforcement.

21.9.5 — Design for flexure and axial loads R21.9.5 — Design for flexure and axial loads
21.9.5.1 — Structural walls and portions of such walls R21.9.5.1 — Flexural strength of a wall or wall segment
subject to combined flexural and axial loads shall be is determined according to procedures commonly used for
designed in accordance with 10.2 and 10.3 except that columns. Strength should be determined considering the
10.3.7 and the nonlinear strain requirements of 10.2.2 applied axial and lateral forces. Reinforcement concentrated
shall not apply. Concrete and developed longitudinal in boundary elements and distributed in flanges and webs
reinforcement within effective flange widths, boundary should be included in the strength computations based on a
elements, and the wall web shall be considered strain compatibility analysis. The foundation supporting the
effective. The effects of openings shall be considered. wall should be designed to develop the wall boundary and
web forces. For walls with openings, the influence of the
opening or openings on flexural and shear strengths is to be
considered and a load path around the opening or openings
should be verified. Capacity-design concepts and strut-and-
tie models may be useful for this purpose.21.47
21.9.5.2 — Unless a more detailed analysis is R21.9.5.2 — Where wall sections intersect to form L-, T-, C-,
performed, effective flange widths of flanged sections or other cross-sectional shapes, the influence of the flange on
shall extend from the face of the web a distance equal the behavior of the wall should be considered by selecting
to the smaller of one-half the distance to an adjacent appropriate flange widths. Tests21.48 show that effective flange
wall web and 25 percent of the total wall height. width increases with increasing drift level and the effectiveness
of a flange in compression differs from that for a flange in
tension. The value used for the effective compression flange
width has little impact on the strength and deformation capacity
of the wall; therefore, to simplify design, a single value of
effective flange width based on an estimate of the effective
tension flange width is used in both tension and compression.

similar to those of the 1995 Code, and have been retained
because they are conservative for assessing required transverse
reinforcement at wall boundaries for many walls. Require-
ments of 21.9.6.4 and 21.9.6.5 apply to structural walls
designed by either 21.9.6.2 or 21.9.6.3.

21.9.8 — Wall piers R21.9.8 — Wall piers
21.9.8.1 — Wall piers shall satisfy the special Door and window placements in structural walls sometimes
moment frame requirements for columns of 21.6.3, lead to narrow vertical wall segments that are considered to be

21.10 — Special structural walls R21.10 — Special structural walls
constructed using precast concrete constructed using precast concrete
21.10.1 — Scope
Requirements of 21.10 apply to special structural walls
constructed using precast concrete forming part of the
seismic-force-resisting system.
21.10.2 — Special structural walls constructed using
precast concrete shall satisfy all requirements of 21.9
in addition to 21.4.2 and 21.4.3.

precast concrete and unbonded post-tensioning have demonstrated that some types of precast structural

5.1 defines a protocol for establishing a design procedure,
validated by analysis and laboratory tests, for such walls,
with or without coupling beams.

21.11 — Structural diaphragms and trusses R21.11 — Structural diaphragms and trusses
21.11.1 — Scope R21.11.1 — Scope
Floor and roof slabs acting as structural diaphragms to Diaphragms as used in building construction are structural
transmit forces induced by earthquake ground motions elements (such as a floor or roof) that provide some or all of
in structures assigned to SDC D, E, or F shall be the following functions:
designed in accordance with this section. This section
also applies to collector elements and trusses forming (a) Support for building elements (such as walls, partitions,
part of the seismic-force-resisting system. and cladding) resisting horizontal forces but not acting as
part of the seismic-force-resisting system;
(b) Transfer of lateral forces from the point of application
to the vertical elements of the seismic-force-resisting system;
(c) Connection of various components of the vertical
seismic-force-resisting system with appropriate strength,
stiffness, and toughness so the building responds as
intended in the design.21.58
21.11.2 — Design forces R21.11.2 — Design forces
The earthquake design forces for structural In the general building codes, earthquake design forces for
diaphragms shall be obtained from the legally adopted floor and roof diaphragms typically are not computed directly
general building code using the applicable provisions during the lateral-force analysis that provides story forces and
and load combinations. story shears. Instead, diaphragm design forces at each level are
computed by a formula that amplifies the story forces recog-
nizing dynamic effects and includes minimum and maximum
limits. These forces are used with the governing load combi-
nations to design diaphragms for shear and moment.
For collector elements, general building codes in use in the
U.S. specify load combinations that amplify earthquake forces
by a factor Ω .The forces amplified byΩ are also used for
o o
local diaphragm shear force resulting from the transfer of
collector forces, and for local diaphragm flexural moments
resulting from any eccentricity of collector forces. The specific
requirements for earthquake design forces for diaphragms
and collectors depend on which general building code is
used. The requirements may also vary according to the SDC.
For most concrete buildings subjected to inelastic earth-
quake demands, it is desirable to limit inelastic behavior of
floor and roof diaphragms under the imposed earthquake
forces and deformations. It is preferable for inelastic
behavior to occur only in the intended locations of the
vertical earthquake-force-resisting system that are detailed
for ductile response, such as in the beam plastic hinges of
special moment frames, or in flexural plastic hinging at the
base of structural walls or in coupling beams. For buildings
without long diaphragm spans between lateral-force-
resisting elements, elastic diaphragm behavior is typically
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 367
CODE COMMENTARY
Fig. R21.11.3.2—Example of diaphragm subject to the
requirements of 21.11.3.2 and showing an element having
confinement as required by 21.11.7.5.
not difficult to achieve. For buildings where diaphragms
could reach their flexural or shear strength before yielding
occurs in the vertical seismic systems, designers should
consider providing increased diaphragm strength.
21.11.3 — Seismic load path R21.11.3 — Seismic load path
21.11.3.1 — All diaphragms and their connections shall
be proportioned and detailed to provide for a complete
transfer of forces to collector elements and to the
vertical elements of the seismic-force-resisting system.
21.11.3.2 — Elements of a structural diaphragm R21.11.3.2 — Section 21.11.3.2 applies to strut-like
system that are subjected primarily to axial forces and elements that often are present around openings,
used to transfer diaphragm shear or flexural forces diaphragm edges, or other discontinuities in diaphragms.
around openings or other discontinuities, shall comply Figure R21.11.3.2 shows an example. Such elements can
with the requirements for collectors in 21.11.7.5 and be subjected to earthquake axial forces in combination
21.11.7.6. with bending and shear from earthquake or gravity loads.

21.11.7 — Reinforcement R21.11.7 — Reinforcement
21.11.7.1 — The minimum reinforcement ratio for R21.11.7.1 — Minimum reinforcement ratios for
structural diaphragms shall be in conformance with diaphragms correspond to the required amount of temperature
7.12. Except for post-tensioned slabs, reinforcement and shrinkage reinforcement (7.12). The maximum spacing
spacing each way in floor or roof systems shall not for web reinforcement is intended to control the width of
exceed 18 in. Where welded wire reinforcement is inclined cracks. Minimum average prestress requirements
used as the distributed reinforcement to resist shear in (7.12.3) are considered to be adequate to limit the crack
topping slabs placed over precast floor and roof widths in post-tensioned floor systems; therefore, the
elements, the wires parallel to the span of the precast maximum spacing requirements do not apply to these systems.
elements shall be spaced not less than 10 in. on
center. Reinforcement provided for shear strength The minimum spacing requirement for welded wire reinforce-
shall be continuous and shall be distributed uniformly ment in topping slabs on precast floor systems (see 21.11.7.1)
across the shear plane. is to avoid fracture of the distributed reinforcement during
an earthquake. Cracks in the topping slab open immediately
above the boundary between the flanges of adjacent precast
members, and the wires crossing those cracks are restrained
by the transverse wires.21.59 Therefore, all the deformation
associated with cracking should be accommodated in a
distance not greater than the spacing of the transverse wires.
A minimum spacing of 10 in. for the transverse wires is
required in 21.11.7.1 to reduce the likelihood of fracture of
the wires crossing the critical cracks during a design earth-
quake. The minimum spacing requirements do not apply to
diaphragms reinforced with individual bars, because strains
are distributed over a longer length.
21.11.7.2 — Bonded tendons used as reinforcement
to resist collector forces or diaphragm shear or flexural
tension shall be proportioned such that the stress due
to design earthquake forces does not exceed 60,000 psi.
Precompression from unbonded tendons shall be
permitted to resist diaphragm design forces if a
seismic load path is provided.

Compressive stress calculated for the factored forces on a
linearly elastic model based on gross section of the structural
diaphragm is used as an index value to determine whether
confining reinforcement is required. A calculated compressive
stress of 0.2f′ in a member, or 0.5f′ for forces amplified by
c c
Ω , is assumed to indicate that integrity of the entire
o
structure depends on the ability of that member to resist
substantial compressive force under severe cyclic loading.
Therefore, transverse reinforcement is required in such
members to provide confinement for the concrete and the
reinforcement.
21.11.7.6 — Longitudinal reinforcement for collector R21.11.7.6 — Section 21.11.7.6 is intended to reduce
elements at splices and anchorage zones shall have the possibility of bar buckling and provide adequate bar
either: development conditions in the vicinity of splices and
anchorage zones.
(a) A minimum center-to-center spacing of three
longitudinal bar diameters, but not less than 1-1/2 in.,
and a minimum concrete clear cover of two and

21.11.8 — Flexural strength R21.11.8 — Flexural strength
Diaphragms and portions of diaphragms shall be Flexural strength for diaphragms is calculated using the
designed for flexure in accordance with 10.2 and 10.3 same assumptions as for walls, columns, or beams. The
except that the nonlinear distribution of strain require- design of diaphragms for flexure and other actions uses the
ments of 10.2.2 for deep beams need not apply. The applicable load combinations of 9.2 to consider earthquake
effects of openings shall be considered. forces acting concurrently with gravity or other loads.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
370 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
The influence of slab openings on flexural and shear strength is
to be considered, including evaluating the potential critical
sections created by the openings. Strut-and-tie models are
potentially useful for designing diaphragms with openings.
Earlier design practice assumed design moments for structural
diaphragms were resisted entirely by chord forces acting at
opposite edges of the diaphragm. This idealization was
implicit in earlier versions of the Code, but has been
replaced by an approach in which all longitudinal reinforce-
ment, within the limits of 21.11.7, is assumed to contribute
to the flexural strength of the diaphragm. This change
reduces the required area of longitudinal reinforcement
concentrated near the edge of the diaphragm, but should not
be interpreted as a requirement to eliminate all boundary
reinforcement.

structural walls resisting forces induced by earthquake

shall be fully developed for tension at the interface.

or loose soil deposit. The Code requirement for confinement

Where precast piles are to be used, the potential for the pile
required in 21.12.4.4(a).
tip to be driven to an elevation different than that specified
in the contract documents needs to be considered when
detailing the pile. If the pile reaches refusal at a shallower
depth, a longer length of pile will need to be cut off. If this
possibility is not foreseen, the length of transverse reinforce-
ment required by 21.12.4.4 may not be available after the
excess pile length is cut off.
21.12.4.5 — For precast concrete driven piles, the
length of transverse reinforcement provided shall be
sufficient to account for potential variations in the
elevation in pile tips.
21.12.4.6 — Concrete piles, piers, or caissons in
foundations supporting one- and two-story stud
bearing wall construction are exempt from the trans-
verse reinforcement requirements of 21.12.4.4 and
21.12.4.5.
21.12.4.7 — Pile caps incorporating batter piles R21.12.4.7 — Extensive structural damage has often been
shall be designed to resist the full compressive observed at the junction of batter piles and the buildings. The
strength of the batter piles acting as short columns. pile cap and surrounding structure should be designed for the
The slenderness effects of batter piles shall be consid- potentially large forces that can be developed in batter piles.
ered for the portion of the piles in soil that is not
capable of providing lateral support, or in air or water.

STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 377
CHAPTER 22 — STRUCTURAL PLAIN CONCRETE
CODE COMMENTARY
22.1 — Scope R22.1 — Scope
22.1.1 — This chapter provides minimum requirements Before the 1995 Code, requirements for plain concrete were
for design and construction of structural plain concrete set forth in “Building Code Requirements for Structural
members (cast-in-place or precast). Plain Concrete (ACI 318.1-89) (Revised 1992).” Require-
ments for plain concrete are now in this Code (see 2.2 for
definition of plain concrete). Limitations are provided in
22.2 to clarify the scope and applicability of this chapter.
See 1.1.4 for requirements for residential construction
within the scope of ACI 332.
22.1.2 — Unless in conflict with the provisions of R22.1.2 — Sections of the Code do not apply to the design of
Chapter 22, the following provisions of this Code shall structural plain concrete for the following specific reasons:
apply to structural plain concrete members: Sections
1.1 through 7.5, 7.6.1, 7.6.2, 7.6.4, 7.7, 9.1.3, 9.2, 9.3.5, Sections 7.6 and 7.8 through 7.13 — These sections
Chapter 20, 21.12.2.5, C.9.2, C.9.3.5, and Appendix D. contain requirements intended for reinforced concrete
members and, with the exception of 7.6.1, 7.6.2, and 7.6.4,
are not applicable to structural plain concrete members, for
which strength is determined only by member size and
concrete strength, and not by reinforcement (see 22.5).
Concrete cover requirements of 7.7 apply to structural plain
concrete members if reinforcement is provided.
Chapters 8 through 19 — These chapters of the Code
contain general and specific design requirements for reinforced
and prestressed concrete members, including walls and
foundations, which are not applicable to structural plain
concrete, except for 9.1.3, 9.2, and 9.3.5 where applicable
load factors and strength reduction factors for structural
plain concrete are specified.
Chapter 21 — This chapter contains seismic design
requirements for reinforced concrete members and is not
applicable to structural plain concrete except in the sections
of the chapter where structural plain concrete is specifically
addressed.
Appendixes A and B — Appendixes A and B are intended
for reinforced concrete members and are not applicable to
structural plain concrete.
22.1.3 — For unusual structures, such as arches,
underground utility structures, gravity walls, and
shielding walls, provisions of this chapter shall govern
where applicable.
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
378 STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY
CODE COMMENTARY
22.2 — Limitations R22.2 — Limitations
22.2.1 — Use of structural plain concrete shall be R22.2.1 and R22.2.2 — Because the strength and structural
limited to (a), (b), or (c): integrity of structural plain concrete members is based
solely on the member size, concrete strength, and other
(a) Members that are continuously supported by soil concrete properties, use of structural plain concrete should
or supported by other structural members capable of be limited to members that are primarily in a state of
providing continuous vertical support; compression, members that can tolerate random cracks
without detriment to their structural integrity, and members
(b) Members for which arch action provides
where ductility is not an essential feature of design. The
compression under all conditions of loading;
tensile strength of concrete can be used in design of struc-
tural plain concrete members. Tensile stresses due to restraint
(c) Walls and pedestals. See 22.6 and 22.8.
from creep, shrinkage, or temperature effects are to be
The use of structural plain concrete columns shall not considered to avoid uncontrolled cracks or structural failure.
be permitted.
Plain concrete walls are permitted (see 22.6) without a height
22.2.2 — This chapter shall not govern design and limitation. However, for multistory construction and other
installation of cast-in-place concrete piles and piers major structures, ACI Committee 318 encourages the use of
embedded in ground. walls designed in accordance with Chapter 14 (see R22.6).
Since plain concrete lacks the necessary ductility that
columns should possess and because a random crack in an
unreinforced column will most likely endanger its structural
integrity, the Code does not permit use of plain concrete for
columns. It does allow its use for pedestals limited to a ratio
of unsupported height to least lateral dimension of 3 or less
(see 22.8.2).
Structural elements such as cast-in-place concrete piles and
piers in ground or other material sufficiently stiff to provide
adequate lateral support to prevent buckling are not covered
by this Code. Such elements are covered by the general
building code.
22.2.3 — Minimum specified strength R22.2.3 — Minimum specified strength
Specified compressive strength of structural plain A minimum specified compressive strength requirement for
concrete shall not be less than the larger of that given structural plain concrete construction is considered necessary
in 1.1.1 and that required for durability in Chapter 4. because performance and safety is based solely on strength
and quality of concrete treated as a homogeneous material.
Lean concrete mixtures may not produce adequately
homogeneous material or well-formed surfaces.
22.2.4 — Lightweight concrete
Modification factor λ for lightweight concrete in this
Chapter shall be in accordance with 8.6.1.
22.3 — Joints R22.3 — Joints
22.3.1 — Contraction or isolation joints shall be Joints in plain concrete construction are an important design
provided to divide structural plain concrete members consideration. In reinforced concrete, reinforcement is
into flexurally discontinuous elements. The size of provided to resist the stresses due to restraint of creep,
each element shall be chosen to limit stress caused by shrinkage, and temperature effects. In plain concrete, joints
restraint to movements from creep, shrinkage, and are the only means of controlling and, thereby, relieving the
temperature effects. buildup of such tensile stresses. A plain concrete member
American Concrete Institute Copyrighted Material—www.concrete.org
STRUCTURAL CONCRETE BUILDING CODE (ACI 318-11) AND COMMENTARY 379
CODE COMMENTARY
22.3.2 — In determining the number and location of should therefore be small enough, or divided into smaller
contraction or isolation joints, consideration shall be elements by joints, to control the buildup of internal
given to: influence of climatic conditions; selection and stresses. The joint may be a contraction joint or an isolation
proportioning of materials; mixing, placing, and curing joint. A minimum 25 percent reduction of member thickness is
of concrete; degree of restraint to movement; stresses considered sufficient for contraction joints to be effective.
due to loads to which an element is subject; and The jointing should be such that no axial tension or flexural
construction techniques. tension can be developed across a joint after cracking, if
applicable—a condition referred to as flexural discontinuity.
Where random cracking due to creep, shrinkage, and
temperature effects will not affect the structural integrity,
and is otherwise acceptable, such as transverse cracks in a
continuous wall footing, transverse contraction, or isolation
joints are not necessary.
22.4 — Design method R22.4 — Design method
22.4.1 — Factored loads and forces shall be in Plain concrete members are proportioned for adequate
combinations as in 9.2. strength using factored loads and forces. When the design
strength is exceeded, the section should be increased or the
22.4.2 — Where required strength exceeds design specified strength of concrete increased, or both, or the
strength, reinforcement shall be provided and the member designed as a reinforced concrete member in
member designed as a reinforced concrete member in accordance with the Code. An increase in concrete section
accordance with appropriate design requirements of may have a detrimental effect; stress due to load will
this Code. decrease but stresses due to creep, shrinkage, and temperature
effects may increase.
22.4.3 — Strength design of structural plain concrete R22.4.3 — Flexural tension may be considered in design of
members for flexure and axial loads shall be based on plain concrete members to sustain loads, provided the
a linear stress-strain relationship in both tension and computed stress does not exceed the permissible stress, and
compression. construction, contraction, or isolation joints are provided to
relieve the resulting tensile stresses due to restraint of creep,
temperature, and shrinkage effects.
22.4.4 — Tensile strength of concrete shall be
permitted to be considered in design of plain concrete
members when provisions of 22.3 have been followed.
22.4.5 — No strength shall be assigned to steel
reinforcement that may be present.
22.4.6 — Tension shall not be transmitted through
outside edges, construction joints, contraction joints, or
isolation joints of an individual plain concrete element. No
flexural continuity due to tension shall be assumed
between adjacent structural plain concrete elements.
22.4.7 — When computing strength in flexure, R22.4.7 — The reduced overall thickness h for concrete
combined flexure and axial load, and shear, the entire cast against earth is to allow for unevenness of excavation
cross section of a member shall be considered in and for some contamination of the concrete adjacent to the
design, except for concrete cast against soil where soil.
overall thickness h shall be taken as 2 in. less than
actual thickness.

22.6 — Walls R22.6 — Walls
22.6.1 — Structural plain concrete walls shall be Plain concrete walls are commonly used for basement wall
continuously supported by soil, footings, foundation construction for residential and light commercial buildings
walls, grade beams, or other structural members in low or nonseismic areas. Although the Code imposes no
capable of providing continuous vertical support. absolute maximum height limitation on the use of plain
concrete walls, experience with use of plain concrete in
22.6.2 — Structural plain concrete walls shall be relatively minor structures should not be extrapolated to
designed for vertical, lateral, and other loads to which using plain concrete walls in multistory construction and
they are subjected. other major structures where differential settlement, wind,
earthquake, or other unforeseen loading conditions require
22.6.3 — Structural plain concrete walls shall be the walls to possess some ductility and ability to maintain
designed for an eccentricity corresponding to the their integrity when cracked. For such conditions, ACI
maximum moment that can accompany the axial load Committee 318 strongly encourages the use of walls
but not less than 0.10h. If the resultant of all factored designed in accordance with Chapter 14.
loads is located within the middle third of the overall
wall thickness, the design shall be in accordance with The provisions for plain concrete walls are applicable only
22.5.3 or 22.6.5. Otherwise, walls shall be designed in for walls laterally supported in such a manner as to prohibit
accordance with 22.5.3. relative lateral displacement at top and bottom of individual
wall elements (see 22.6.6.4). The Code does not cover walls
22.6.4 — Design for shear shall be in accordance with without horizontal support to prohibit relative displacement
22.5.4. at top and bottom of wall elements. Such laterally unsup-
ported walls are to be designed as reinforced concrete
members in accordance with the Code.
